item.title: Ballarat Pop-Up Shop
item.description:
Opening the holiday gift-buying season, Pop-Up Co. brings you, for the third year, the Ballarat Pop-Up Shop - an exclusive retail shopping event featuring quality goods from some of our region's best designers and makers.
The Ballarat Pop-Up Shop is an annual Christmas event. Find that perfect gift for someone special!
Open only six days over two weekends - Friday 10am-9pm, Saturday & Sunday 10am-4pm.

item.title: Australia Day at Avoca
item.description:
Avoca is hosting Council's Australia Day Celebrations in 2015. Join in the celebrations from 8.30am, with a barbecue in the centre of town, before taking part in activities including a scavenger hunt, barefoot bowls, or watching a demonstration of petanque.
The formal celebrations start at 11.30am in Avoca Public Park with the presentation of Citizen of the Year Award, Young Citizen of the Year Award and the Community Event of the Year, followed by lunch. Finish the day off with a swim in the pool. Keep an eye out for a full program as the day approaches.

item.title: Beaufort Vinduro
item.description:
VERi presents a non-competitive vintage enduro event for pre‐1985 trail and enduro bikes. Riders must have a valid licence, and bikes must be registered (permits available, but get in quick!).
Bikes should have adequate silencing. Practice track available Saturday, main event on Sunday. Camping available. Spectators welcome on Saturday afternoon grass track 'settle in' session opposite Raglan Reserve and at the 9am cold test Sunday.

item.title: Broadford Community Garden Working Bee
item.description:
The Broadford Community Garden is a welcoming place that strengthens community spirit, embraces diversity and encompasses organic and sustainable principles throughout the garden and conservation areas.
The next working bee will be on Sunday 30 November 2014.
Bring boots, gloves and a shovel - they are digging paths in the main vegie garden area.
Kicking off at 10am, register in the main room at the Broadford Community Centre.
BBQ lunch at 1pm to celebrate the latest achievement.
For more info and to view the Master Plan check them out on Facebook!

item.title: Unravelling the Mysteries of Human Consciousness
item.description:
What is it to be aware? What makes people conscious? The complexities of consciousness have intrigued philosophers and scientists for thousands of years, but can modern neuroscience ever hope to understand this phenomenon?
From philosophers and ethicists to neuroscientists, this panel of experts, including Baroness Professor Susan Greenfield, will discuss the topic of consciousness.

item.title: Tracking with the Pitcha Makin Fellaz Exhibition
item.description:
Come and see the twelve giant animal designs created by kids at ArtPlay with the Pitcha Makin Fellaz. The Fellaz are a group of 7 Aboriginal men from Ballarat who create art together and have developed their own unique style. The kids explored aboriginal stories of the Yarra and worked with the Fellaz to learn their techniques. Using stamps, paint and patterns they created 2-metre high animals.
Everyone is invited to the launch party at 3pm on Sunday 2 November at ArtPlay (drinks & nibbles provided).
The Pitcha Makin Fellaz are: Myles Walsh, Peter-Shane Rotumah, Adrian Rigney, Ted Laxton, Thomas Marks, Billy Blackall and Joe Lee. Assisted by Peter Widmer
Age: Family Launch: Sunday 2 November, 3pm Exhibition open: Wednesday 29 October to Sunday 23 November (Wed to Sun only) Cost: Free, no bookings required
All children under eight years must be accompanied by an adult.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: The Smoking Owl
item.description:
Once a month, Gallery One Three presents The Smoking Owl, a non-profit night that supports work by fresh local talent seeking ways to develop exciting and innovative concepts in their art practice. The Smoking Owl is a fusion of music, art and festivities.
November's Smoking Owl presents Memory & Absence, video art by Nicholas Polson and Eamonn Connor. This exhibition of video art explores the intersection of matter and memory through a reworking of archival and original footage. These images manipulate the presence of bodies in various spaces, both imagined and real, examining the way in which we orientate the present through the insertion of relevant memories. The works construct a space of confused temporality: a visual field that is lodged in the past, contemplating the present.
Performing alongside the video works is Ricochet, a collaborative project formed by four improvising Melbourne musicians. The quartet investigates the concept of performance-based composition, where music is constructed and arranged in the context of a live performance. Compositional elements such as rhythmic cycles, functional harmony, atonality and abstractionism are used to blend the group's influences (contemporary minimalism, free jazz, hip hop, rock and other world folk music) into a cohesive musical experience. The resulting performance pieces are unrepeatable, a unique product of the time and place in which they are made.
Upon arrival to The Smoking Owl each guest will be given a mask to wear throughout the evening. The mask allows audience members to feel part of the performance/exhibition. It invites them into the theatre of the evening and creates a unified masquerade of like-minded people.

item.title: The Sea, The Shore
item.description:
Meg Cowell’s The Sea, The Shore exhibition presents a series of large-scale photographic works that illustrate a ritual shift from garment to artefact.
Ritual dress accompanies many important rites of passage. For women, white wedding gowns and Victorian mourning attire are iconic artefacts that carry their wearer from one stage of life to the next. In turn, it is not beauty, vanity or a political reading of fashion that concerns Cowell’s practice. Instead, it is the moment when a woman dons a costume for her transformation that is of interest. For the artist, such occasions elevate garments beyond their materiality to become an embodiment of female ritual.
The Sea, The Shore presents a series of large-scale photographic works that illustrate this shift from garment to artefact. Through sophisticated direction, Meg Cowell creates vignettes of unique gowns, lingerie and couture as they bloom into new forms: for example, dresses appear flower-like, floating in the abyss.
Meg Cowell graduated with Honours in Photography from the University of Tasmania in 2007, and has gone on to exhibit nationally and abroad. This is her first solo exhibition at Flinders Lane Gallery.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: The Other Mother
item.description:
Transgressing the traditional image of mother and child, this exhibition acknowledges the unspoken, dark side of the maternal experience.
It is difficult for those of us who haven’t experienced motherhood to understand the complexity of the emotions it engenders.
Exhaustion and sleep deprivation go hand-in-hand with profound, selfless love and the powerful instinct of protection. Yet these widely discussed and socially accepted parts of the role are much easier to express than the anxiety, feelings of inadequacy, anger and guilt that most mothers face at one point or another. Rebecca Hastings’ work speaks of the uncomfortable and often conflicting emotions that can accompany motherhood, employing humour and a generous sense of play to diffuse darker themes that permeate her paintings.
Rebecca’s first solo show ‘Disquiet’ at the Flinders Lane Gallery in 2013 was a sell-out. In 2014, Rebecca was announced as a finalist in both the Archibald and the Sulman art prizes.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: South Wharf's Toast to the Spit Roast
item.description:
Come to South Wharf for a fiesta of barbecues, grills and spit roasts from a host of great restaurants, including The Bohemian, The Common Man and Meat Market, plus guests San Telmo. These chefs will be showcasing some incredible meats and techniques, and there'll be artisan beers from Coopers Brewing and wines from Innocent Bystander to complement them.
There'll be live music from 1pm to 5pm, so come on down for that great barbecue atmosphere.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Slipping Away: New Works by Dorota Connellan
item.description:
Slipping Away is a solo exhibition of new works by Polish-Australian artist Dorota Connellan.
Dorota's oil paintings are a surreal deployment of imagination where the landscape and figures blend harmoniously in colourful compositions and atmospheres, floating in an unknown time and space, in a world of dream and imagination.
After predominantly depicting portraits, still life, landscapes, city architecture and issues of human rights, Dorota commenced working from imagination in 2013, creating works which evoke surreal, spiritual and mystical emotional responses.
Slipping Away was produced by Multicultural Arts Victoria as part of a long-running partnership initiated with Fo Guang Yuan Art Gallery.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Royal Park BioBlitz
item.description:
Come along to enjoy a walking BioBlitz of Royal Park and learn about conducting bee, bug, butterfly and flora surveys from a range of horticulture and entomology experts.
Tours leave from concurrently from both Ross Straw Pavilion and Walmsley House at 10am and 12.30pm.
Presented by Urban Landscapes at City of Melbourne.

item.title: No-Bell Prize
item.description:
How difficult is it for neuroscience-related academics and researchers to speak in layman's terms when describing their research? Watch on as six of the brightest academics go up against the bell in a fast-paced competition to crown the 'No-bell' prize!
This fun event will be chaired by Dr Shane Huntington, Executive Officer, Faculty of Medicine, Dentistry and Health Sciences and host of 3RRR's Science Program.
The judges are: - The Hon Adam Bandt MP, Federal Member for Melbourne, Australian Greens Deputy Leader - Associate Professor Megan Munsie, Policy and Outreach Manager and Head of Education, Ethics, Law & Community Awareness Unit Head, Stem Cells Australia - Dr Lauren Ayton, Vision Researcher and Science Communicator, Centre for Eye Research Australia and Bionic Vision Australia.
The contestants are: - Dr Emma Burrows, Research Officer, Behavioural Neuroscience - Associate Professor Helmut Butzkueven, Deputy Director, Melbourne Brain Centre at the Royal Melbourne Hospital - Dr Simon Murray, Laboratory Head, Department of Anatomy and Cell Biology - Dr Michele Veldsman, Postdoctoral Research Fellow, Stroke - Professor Stan Skafidas, Director, Centre for Neural Engineering.

item.title: North: Excerpts and Essays
item.description:
North excerpts and essays meander the wide-ranging north Queensland landscape from Julie Poulsen's home town of Cairns to the Atherton Tablelands onto Cooktown via the Savannah Way. The interpreted views are mixed elucidations: a broad perspective of the far north Queensland landscape.
These works are often viewed flattened and aerial to allow room for intrinsic local details. Here and there is the cat, the goat, the llama, the horse, the letter box, the mailman, the plumber, the peacock, the chook - all part of the local landscape and its ever revolving story.

item.title: Libraries and Learning: Borrowing from Digital?
item.description:
A Melbourne Conversations at the Dock. The growth of mobile and informal learning has meant that libraries and community spaces are changing and stepping up. Through new approaches to learning and creative digital technology, libraries are cultivating and employing "digital literacy", imperative for lifelong learning, work and civic belonging.
Famous educator, ICT expert and advocate of fun and games, Professor Stephen Heppell will join with local creative technologist Brad Hammond and City Of Melbourne Library Services Manager Paula Kelly, to discuss what learning looks like today and what it might look like tomorrow. (PS they still have books!)
Panellists:
Professor Stephen Heppell - Educator, Teacher, Academic and CEO of Heppell.net, UK Brad Hammond - Creative Technologist and Director of Ethno Tekh, Melbourne Paula Kelly - Library Services Manager, City of Melbourne MC Peter Mares - Writer, Journalist, Researcher and Academic
Brad Hammond is the City of Melbourne's Inaugural Knowledge Fellow supported by the Copyright Agency Limited Cultural Fund and ISS Institute. Professor Heppell is supported by the ISS Institute, as an international visiting fellow. Special thanks to Knowledge Melbourne and Melbourne Library Service.

item.title: Kingston Central Plaza
item.description:
Join in on all the fun at Kingston Central Plaza's Community Day on Saturday 15th November!
Come down for a day of FREE entertainment and a host of family activities including a petting zoo, balloon artist and face painting!
Highlights of the day will include the KCP Cook-Off, a competition set to showcase the best local culinary talent from 12pm-1pm.
Win great prizes including a flight to a King Valley Winery with Kirkhope Aviation.
Explore a 'hands-on' cockpit display from the Australian National Aviation Museum and enjoy the local tunes of the Joyful Strains Choir.
The Kingston Central Plaza Community Day will be held from 10am-3pm at 288 Centre Dandenong Rd. on Moorabbin Airport & next to DFO.
See you there!
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Jubilation
item.description:
Take time out this holiday season to hop aboard a fire truck, wish upon a floating lantern and have some Christmas fun at the inaugural Docklands Jubilation festival.
Jubilation is a new three-day festival of lights, community, food and entertainment, to show gratitude for the CFA. Come along and start a new Christmas tradition while supporting Victoria's volunteer firefighters.
Event highlights include light installations, floating lanterns, Christmas markets, 18 food trucks across the three days, a carousel, over 10 fire trucks (vintage to modern), illuminated boats in the harbour, the City of Melbourne Christmas tree, live entertainment and appearances from Santa and CFA’s Captain Koala and Beepa.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Hexasonic
item.description:
A sonic feast for the senses, Hexasonic brings together artists of the Ableton Live User Group Melbourne and their unique styles for a united sound experiment.
With each act bringing a 20 to 30-minute set of their own audio flavour to the table, styles range from ambient and electro-acoustic to EDM and IDM. There’ll be live looping, real-time FX processing and live remixing of original and improvised electronica.
Step into the Hexadome – Arts Centre Melbourne's new pop-up space – live and undercover on the Theatres Forecourt for two nights only.
Ableton Live User Group Melbourne is a broad community of both professional and amateur music producers who are drawn together with the intention of sharing musical and production ideas.
The group welcomes all attendees, no matter what level of experience they have with Ableton Live, and offers a chance to meet with other producers, share knowledge, get feedback and hang out with other like-minded enthusiasts.
Free sessions are held each month at Arts Centre Melbourne, in which both guest speakers and group members are encouraged to get up and show their latest work, production techniques and live sets.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Divine Agencies
item.description:
Throughout the ages, different religions have had visions of messengers of the gods. This exhibition explores the different concepts called angels, seraphim, cherubim, and the various mythologies surrounding angelic winged creatures.
The paintings explore different mythological representations of angels from several cultures, past and present, from the beautifully colored multi-wing angels of Islam to the different choirs of angels in Christianity, to Hindu Kinnari and Taoist Tian Shi.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Choose Happiness - A Free Talk
item.description:
Join internationally renowned teacher and Buddhist Nun, Gen-la Kelsang Dekyong, at Federation Square in the heart of Melbourne for a life-changing free public talk on happiness.
Each and every one us is able to tap in to an endless supply of inner peace and happiness. Modern Buddhism presents the meditation and positive thinking techniques we need to achieve this. At this event, open to everyone, Gen-la Dekyong will explain the methods that free us from negative emotions, making joy and happiness our everyday reality. Choose happiness for 2015. Everyone is welcome. Bring a cushion.
THE TEACHER Gen-la Kelsang Dekyong, General Spiritual Director of the NKT- IKBU, is a modern Buddhist nun dedicated to helping people from all walks of life attain lasting happiness through developing inner, mental peace. Gen-la is loved and respected throughout the world for the sincerity of her practice and the power of her wisdom and compassion.
EVENT INFORMATION Cost free - no need to book - bring a cushion.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Book Launch: A Soul for Australia?
item.description:
Join Professor Richard Freadman as he launches the book 'A Soul for Australia? Reading Fosco Antonio's My Reality', edited by John Gutt-Rutter and Peter Willis, and guides readers through its turbulent pages.
Fosco Antonio's polemical text is republished in this volume, accompanied by six exploratory essays ranging from the supportive to the dismissive, which seek to open up the debate on the issues Antonio poses.

item.title: Loch Sport Community Market
item.description:
Come and browse through stalls of jewellery, cakes, books, paintings, Balinese items, wood work, craft, Christmas craft, candles, soaps and odds and ends.
Indoor/outdoor variety market featuring BBQ, cakes, refreshments, bric a brac, craft, plants and garden ornaments. Will be held from 8am to 2pm at Loch Sport Public Hall.
Snack on a sausage or Devonshire Tea. All proceeds will be donated to the Golden Beach Wildlife Shelter. There will be some of the animals at the market.

item.title: Maffra Variety and Farmers Market
item.description:
Maffra comes alive the first Sunday of every month, with producers, farmers and many more coming together in Johnson Street.
Maffra Variety and Farmers Market specialises in fresh seafood, farm fresh vegetables, jams/preserves, pet food and accessories.
All your favourite producers and stallholders will be on hand.
Handmade soaps/candles, crafts, plants bric-a-brac and much more.

item.title: Grassroots Market
item.description:
The very successful Grassroots Market is being held in Main Street in Upwey this November.
The market will feature 85 stalls selling local artisan products. The Grassroots Market can help you with your Christmas shopping with clothes, shoes, handbags, crafts, art, ceramics, glass, jewellery and more.
There will be food and entertainment to sustain you as you shop.

item.title: Wallan Carols by Candlelight
item.description:
The 2014 Wallan Carols by Candlelight will be once again held in the R. B. Robson Stadium Wallan, with the usual food court outside selling a variety of food and drink. This year there will be the added bonus of fun-filled children's activities.
The carols performance will be between 7:30pm and 9:00pm. The food court and children's activities will open at 6:00pm. Santa will make an early appearance for those families who wish to have a photo taken with him before the carols start. He will also make a special time to visit everyone all towards the end of the program.
Entrance is free. All welcome to this alcohol-free event. Mark your calendar now and they look forward to seeing you on the 20th December!

item.title: Illuminate
item.description:
Illuminate will transform the Box Hill Town Hall with a projection show that weaves images, sound and multimedia in a celebration of the 20th anniversary of the City of Whitehorse.
The Illuminate Projection Show is a stunning visual reel of Whitehorse footage and animation projected onto the stark white façade of the Town Hall - transforming it into a colourful, vivid work of art. Accompanying the commission is a dramatic musical score created from the archives of the City's much loved Whitehorse Orchestra.
Come and see the finished 'Big White Horse'. Standing at an impressive 5 metres, this beautiful bamboo creature will be crafted in the foyer of the Town Hall and decorated using thousands of white flowers created by the students from 16 schools across Whitehorse. The community is invited to contribute to this work of art from 10.30am to 4pm on Tuesday 25 November, and assist the artist as she covers the horse in its flowery shroud.
The opening night festival will be held on Friday 28 November, 6.30 to 10.30pm
Join them for a night of free festival fun as the Town Hall is taken over inside and out with live music, exciting art installations, free interactive workshops, face painting, kids' activities and a special 'silent disco'.

item.title: Merbein Great Australian Vanilla Slice Triumph
item.description:
The Merbein Great Australian Vanilla Slice Triumph incorporating the National Dried Fruit Bake-off, is an annual all day culinary event. The event has as its focal point, a baking competition - the iconic vanilla slice, sultana muffin, sunmuscat slice and plum pudding.
It is open to all professional bakers, apprentices, amateurs and students Australia wide. A display marquee enables the public to view all baking competition entries. The culinary event will also feature continuous cooking demonstrations by a variety of chefs, including the event's ambassador, foodie, beverage and produce stalls, a High Tea and a diverse variety of foods to eat.
This will be complemented by free fun activities for the children, an art show and a variety of craft and photographic displays.

image.altText: Merbein Great Australian Vanilla Slice Triumph
Merbein Great Australian Vanilla Slice Triumph

item.title: The Age Good Food Month
item.description:
As if November in Melbourne couldn't get any better, The Age Good Food Month presented by Citi bolts out of the gates with a bumper program of culinary delights celebrating Victoria's world-class food and drinking scene.
In its second year, Good Food Month returns with a line-up of culinary greats, including chef, restaurateur, author and all-round global sensation Yotam Ottolenghi; Italy's biggest skinny Italian chef and contemporary art doyen Massimo Bottura; and arguably one of the most important food thinkers of this time and the woman who put a kitchen garden in The White House, Alice Waters, making her first ever trip to Australia.
Alongside this stellar field of imports are local stars such as The Age Good Food Guide Chef of the Year Andrew McConnell, Melbourne's favourite son Shannon Bennett of Vue de Monde, and rising challengers like Dave Verheul of The Town Mouse - all part of the action-packed program of more than 350 events.
Melburnians can expect an opening weekend full of fire and flavour, smoke and sizzle with Saturday's day of Barbecue Madness. Take your pick from beers and rare-breed meats by the river at The General Assembly at South Wharf, Meatmother's hot chicken challenge, Thai Beach BBQ at Red Spice Road and the food truck barbecue cook-off at the Testing Grounds in Southbank.
Good Food Month has every meal of the day covered with Breakfast Club, Let's Do Lunch, Hats Off Dinners, Good Dinners Under $30 and Let's Do Dessert menus all on offer.

image.altText: GOOD FOOD MONTH IS HERE - MELBOURNE’S OTHER SPRING CARNIVAL
GOOD FOOD MONTH IS HERE - MELBOURNE’S OTHER SPRING CARNIVAL

item.title: Taste the Yarra Valley
item.description:
For the first time ever Cherryhill will be holding, Taste the Yarra Valley, a pre-season festival to celebrate the amazing food and drink producers from around the Yarra Valley.
This is a free event so bring your friends and family and enjoy a great day out whilst trying some delicious produce. This will also be the first day you will be able to buy cherries direct from Cherryhill this season! For more information please call operator.

item.title: The Royal Family Fun Day
item.description:
A family fun day, to coincide with the launch of new Sunshine West residential estate The Royal, will take place in Buckingham Reserve on 9 November 2014, with free food, entertainment, kids activities and an exclusive giveaway of the Vietnamese delicacy Bánh Chu'ng.
As well as the free giveaway of these special cakes, the event will feature face painting, an animal farm, a jumping castle and entertainment by Tubby and Little Tub.
After working up a sweat on the nearby play equipment, or after colouring and then flying a specially designed kite, families can enjoy a sausage sizzle put on by the local Lions Club, or try Vietnamese rice paper rolls made by a local Vietnamese restaurant.

item.title: Abbotsford Convent Open & Tenth birthday
item.description:
The Abbotsford Convent has been open to the public as an arts and cultural site for ten years now!
Each year they celebrate this accomplishment with a special Open Day that invites the public to venture beyond their usual haunts to visit the private studios and workplaces that fill the buildings. For those who are unfamiliar with the Convent, the tenth birthday Open Day is the perfect showcase for the unique Convent site that was saved from developers and gifted to the community ten years ago.
Please come along and enjoy a program of activities including open studios, workspaces, free tours, live music and performances, free workshops, markets, exhibitions, food and drink.
Parking on the day will be limited so please feel free to walk, ride or catch public transport. The Convent will supply a regular free shuttle bus service from Victoria Park station plus extra bicycle parking facilities.

item.title: Swimming in Sand; Growing Rice under an Umbrella
item.description:
Swimming in Sand; Growing Rice under an Umbrella is a collection of ambitious projects from Southeast Asia's new generation of leading contemporary artists.
The exhibition presents artworks by eight artists from Southeast Asia: Alfredo and Isabel Aquilizan (Philippines/Australia), Chan Dany (Cambodia), Khvay Samnang (Cambodia), Nge Lay (Myanmar), Nguyen Thi Thanh Mai (Vietnam), Phan Quang (Vietnam) and Piyarat Piyapongwiwat (Thailand).
Encompassing photography, video, installation and textile the works focus on local concerns that intersect with global forces, providing Australian audiences with a unique insight into how the regions ground-breaking artists are creatively investigating the world around them
Curated by Phnom Penh based curator Roger Nelson and art consultant Anita Archer, this exhibition is supported by a public program of events, workshops and screenings as part of Multicultural Arts Victoria's Mapping Melbourne 2014.
For more information on the artists, artworks and the program of events, visit the website.

image.altText: Swimming in Sand; Growing Rice under an Umbrella
Swimming in Sand; Growing Rice under an Umbrella

item.title: Audi E-Tron Test Driving Experience
item.description:
Melbournians are in for a treat this November as they will be among the first people in Australia to experience the revolutionary Audi A3 Sportback e-tron, the first Audi plug-in hybrid electric vehicle. This pre-launch event will offer you unprecedented access to the German luxury brand's newest technology, well in advance of the official Australian public introduction in March 2015.
This complimentary event will include an Audi e-tron driving experience, led by Audi's Chief Driving Instructor Steve Pizzati of Top Gear fame, and his experienced team of professional racing car drivers. You will have the opportunity to experience the innovative e-tron silent electric engine, on the custom-designed circuit at high speed.
The public is invited to experience the A3 Sportback e-tron that will be available from Thursday 13th to Sunday 16th November at the Melbourne International Karting Complex. With winding tracks and unique terrain, the event is going to be filled with activities you won't want to miss, such as a driving tutorial by Steve Pizzati, Australia's favourite race car driver.
Audi Ambassador, Shannon Bennett, will provide complimentary hospitality for the event, with cuisine inspired by his fabulous new eatery, Jardin Tan, as you enjoy our e-tron clubhouse.
This drive experience is free! To register for this drive experience, visit their website.

address.address1: Corner of Todd Rd and Cook St

item.title: Nagambie WW1 Commemorative week
item.description:
World War One Commemoration week of activities will be held in Nagambie from 8 to 16 November 2014.
November 8 to 15 there will be displays at the museum, library and RSL rooms. November 9 there will be a Ecumenical service at St John's 11am. Bring and share lunch. November 12 a Remembrance day ceremony will be held at cenotaph 10.30am.
A street parade along High Street will be held on November 15 with vehicles and marchers. Featuring Creswick RSL, light horse troop and Euroa Citizens band, military and local groups
On November 15 there will be a commemoration ceremony at RSL grounds at 2.30pm followed by afternoon tea, displays and entertainment. In the evening there will be a WW1 Commemoration dinner.
For details and exact dates please call operators.

item.title: Wallan Secondary College Family Fun Day
item.description:
On Saturday 29th November 2014 from 9am to 2pm, Wallan Secondary College is hosting their very first Family Fun Day.
This will coincide with the State Election, during which Wallan Secondary College will act as a voting centre. The Family Fun Day will have something for everyone. Rides for all ages, side show alley with games and show bags, fantastic food, markets, raffles, art display, entertainment and an animal farm, you will have plenty to see and do.
All day ride wrist bands are $30 (until 24/11/14, $40 after this date), on sale online and at the school office.
Family Fun Day will have a Poster judging competition at 10am, Santa arrives at 11am and at 12pm there will be a world record attempt - gold coin donation for Movember, all can join in
Stall Holders are still wanted, call operator for further details.

item.title: Mos & Mobiles: Growing & Cultivating Mobile Customer Engagement
item.description:
With mobile use higher than ever MitchelLake has partnered with Movember and pulled together some of the leaders across mobile to learn from their approaches using mobile technology in order to drive customer acquisition and engagement.
They would love for you to join them for this educational, interactive and inspirational event as you hear from an exciting panel of storytellers including David Smith, Movember Foundation; James Noble, Carter Digital: & Mark Oliver, Tigerspike with a final speaker to be announced shortly.
This will be a unique opportunity to hear not only the successes but the challenges that have pushed the speakers to be leaders in their field. They look forward to seeing you there.
This is a free event so spread it far and wide. Event runs from 6.30 to 8pm.

image.altText: Mos & Mobiles: Growing & Cultivating Mobile Customer Engagement
Mos & Mobiles: Growing & Cultivating Mobile Customer Engagement

item.title: Fluid Festival at York on Lilydale
item.description:
Fluid Festival at the York on Lilydale will showcase some of the Australia's best beers, ciders and wines. The event will feature stalls from over 15 local and international suppliers, offering the chance to sample a huge range of flavours and styles.
In addition to tastings, you will have the opportunity to meet some of the best in the business at the Meet the Brewer master classes.
Kicking off at 11 am, finishing about 4.30 pm, the event is free to attend all day. Stands will be set up outside at the rear of the hotel near the Lake. Great food will also be available, ranging from Bavarian sausages to Hot Roast Beef Rolls off the Spit.
There will be plenty of entertainment on the day catering for families including an inflatable maze, inflatable castle, miniature animal farm, face painting, and much more.
Also there will be a stage set up featuring Bedrock with Lead Singer none other than Lee Harding from Australian Idol and Secret Empire.
To pre-purchase taste tokens and save money head to their website. Taste tickets available on day.
The York on Lilydale is one of the popular hotels in the Yarra Ranges, offering accommodation, dining, entertainment and conference facilities, and is located about 40 minutes from the city at the foot of Mt Dandenong.

item.title: Melbourne's Mystery Market
item.description:
Melbourne Mystery Market is an Indie fashion and designer market which supports independent designers and low- run labels.
It was known as the North Melbourne Market, but was revamped and made more exciting. It is now popping up in more locations, each location encompassing a new atmosphere creating a new experience.

item.title: How to get 20 clients in 20 hours
item.description:
Are you tired of working really hard but not getting the clients you deserve?
Would you like to get clients more quickly and easily?
Imagine getting new clients right away! Or starting a new business from scratch and being successful quickly. At "How to get 20 clients in 20 hours", you will finally start to see how you can get clients consistently to create an ongoing stream of income. You will be blown away by how simple it is for you to get more clients through the door.
Here is what you will learn in this information-packed day:
Part 1: Setting the foundations so you can build a strong business. Part 2: Attracting your ideal clients and making great sales. Part 3: Putting it all together for quick results. As well as bonus resources and other secrets will be shared on the day.
Too busy to attend? Then maybe you should be attending! If you are too busy that means you could be much more effective.
At the event you will have a single day to focus solely on your business and how to improve it. You will also have fantastic network opportunities with other successful small business owners and entrepreneurs.
Don't put it off. Show your business a little love. Learn how to get 20 clients in 20 hours now!

item.title: Element
item.description:
Element is a Latrobe Regional Gallery and Gippsland Art Gallery Collection Exhibition.
Stephen Wickham's large brooding photographs of snow covered rocks stimulated the search for works from the Latrobe Regional Gallery and Gippsland Art Gallery collections that freeze, sparkle, burn, melt and embed themselves in the landscape. The works selected create new associations with raw, tangible materials and consider how far physical elements form a strong part of creating meaning.

image.altText: Stephen Wickham, From Stefan Weisz for Georg Weisz #1, 2000,

item.title: Illumination: The art of Philip Wolfhagen exhibition opening
item.description:
Hamilton Art Gallery is delighted to present Illumination: The art of Philip Wolfhagen, opening to the public on Wednesday 12 November at 6:30pm.
This is the first major survey exhibition of the work of Philip Wolfhagen, a Tasmanian artist widely regarded as one of Australia's finest contemporary landscape painters.
Wolfhagen is described as a master of creating works that capture changing light, mood and atmosphere. He considers himself a stay-at-home kind of artist.
The exhibition will be officially opened by Ron Ramsey, Development Manager at the Ian Potter Museum of Art, on Wednesday 12 November at 6:30pm. The public is invited to view the exhibition and enjoy a selection of local wines with canapés by talented chef Georgie Sevior of Candied Lime catering.
Further information on this exhibition and the opening can be found on Hamilton Art Gallery's website or by calling operator.

image.altText: The art of Philip Wolfhagen exhibition opening
The art of Philip Wolfhagen exhibition opening

item.title: Wandong Wallan Lions Club Information Session
item.description:
The Wandong Wallan Lions Club will be holding an information afternoon at the Hidden Valley Country Club in Hidden Valley on Saturday 8th November from 2pm to 4pm.
Come along and find out what Lions Clubs are all about and enjoy some wine and cheese while your are there. They would love to update you on what the Club is doing for the local community.

item.title: Vinyl Lounge
item.description:
Come to a record lover's paradise, when the MPavilion hosts the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia's (NFSA) Vinyl Lounge.
Already an institution in Canberra, the Vinyl Lounge sees the NFSA's sound gurus, Thorsten Kaeding and Graham McDonald, play rare and fascinating records from the national collection, and gives the audience a chance to share (and show off) some of their own vinyl.
Melburnians shouldn't miss this chance to enjoy music the way it was meant to be heard, all within the relaxed atmosphere of MPavilion.
MPavilion is a unique architecture commission and design event for Melbourne, initiated by the Naomi Milgrom Foundation with support from City of Melbourne and the Victorian State Government.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: 'Till Death by Julia deVille
item.description:
'Till Death is an exhibition of new precious stone rings by acclaimed artist and taxidermist Julia deVille, presented by e.g.etal, contemporary jewellery and objects.
This new body of work comprises intricately handcrafted large cluster dress rings in silver and gold - often an amalgamation of new gems set alongside old-cut stones reclaimed from antique rings. Each ring has the appearance of a collection of family heirlooms that have been melded gracefully into one piece.
The exhibition's name, 'Till Death, reflects not only the pieces' intended use as engagement rings and tokens of affection, but also evokes deVille's fascination with the acceptance of death. Julia deVille is inspired by the memento mori jewellery of the 15th to 18th centuries, as well as the methods the Victorians used to sentimentalise death with adornment. The artist incorporates symbols of death throughout her work - a celebration of life through an acknowledgement of your own mortality.

item.title: The Festival of Change
item.description:
The Festival of Change is a three-day educational festival that is about inspiring and helping people to make a change in their life, be it career, health, image or lifestyle.
The Festival includes over 150 free, interactive events and workshops across the areas of design, fashion, beauty, health, food, hospitality and business.
Festival highlights: - Keynote address by Jeremy Macvean of Movember - Superfoods rooftop market - Laughter yoga - 'Simple Choices Change the World' talk by Thankyou Movement - Pop-up design market - Street party with live DJ and performances by Strange Fruit - Chocolate meditation workshop - Smartphone photography course - Graduate art exhibition
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: New World Dreaming
item.description:
Melbourne is built on the footprints of immigrants, most of whom came through the port and docklands.
In the 1850s Andrew's Irish great-great-grandparents fled the blighted potato fields of Donegal and reached Melbourne, via India in rebellion. They arrived in Melbourne in summer, to a welcome of bushfires, wild dogs and news of the Great Melbourne Telescope gazing at the heavens.
Peter's in-laws left Calabria in the 1950s, where the war had destroyed the established order in their village. Women did men's work and men, especially the ones who had been prisoners of war, had glimpsed other ways of life. When the old order began to reassert itself those who expected more of life had to look elsewhere. Peter's in-laws headed for Melbourne.
Andrew and Peter are seasoned storytellers and in this intimate production they use music and spoken word to give expression to the lives of a few of the millions fleeing the stagnation and turmoil of old worlds to make a life for themselves in a new one.

item.title: National Novel Writing Month: Writing Sessions for Teens
item.description:
Teens, are you tackling the National Novel Writing Month challenge this November?
On Mondays and Wednesdays in November, National Novel Writing Month, drop by to connect with other teen writers and spur on your word count with mid-week sessions.
On Saturdays in November, get hands-on and troubleshoot your work-in-progress at a weekend session hosted by a Young Adult author.

item.title: Mazda Opera in the Bowl
item.description:
It's a Saturday evening in summer and you are sitting in a park with family and friends and a fabulous picnic dinner. The picture is completed when the glorious live music begins, especially when the music is some of the most-loved opera choruses and arias from four leading soloists, the Opera Australia Chorus and Orchestra Victoria. This marvellous combination could only be Mazda Opera in the Bowl.
This free concert celebrates the magic and memorable moments in opera. Staged at the Sidney Myer Music Bowl - one of the country's premier open-air venues - Mazda Opera in the Bowl features some of the greatest arias and most beautiful overtures in a fantastic program of songs and duets that is sure to delight opera aficionados and novices alike.
The line-up features dazzling soprano Natalie Aroyan, gorgeous mezzo-soprano Sian Pendry; tender-hearted tenor Diego Torre; and commanding baritones Andrew Jones and Shane Lowrencev. The program include exhilarating chorus pieces from La Traviata and Il Trovatore; popular opera arias from Carmen, Madama Butterfly and Turandot, and, of course, the most loved of all duets from The Pearl Fishers.
This family-friendly event is presented by Opera Australia's Principal Partner Mazda Australia, who are committed to introducing opera to a wider audience.

item.title: First Friday Dance Club
item.description:
Shake your way into the weekend with a free dance class at Queensbridge Square.
On the first Friday of each month, at the same time, in the same place, people come together to dance. Each month it's a different genre, and each month anyone in Melbourne can come into the city and learn a dance with skilled dancing groups.
The site becomes known as a place for dancing. The first Friday becomes known as the night for dancing.
The First Friday Dance Club is produced by the City of Melbourne's Arts and Participation program. Led by community and professional dance groups, it provides opportunities for people to come together to learn, share and experience dance.
First Friday Dance Club is free, lo-fi, and open to all ages.

item.title: Engineering a Better World
item.description:
Engineering and technology are fundamental to a life of opportunity free from poverty. They underpin resilient, sustainable communities through the provision of access to clean water, sanitation, renewable energy, shelter, transport, communications, education and health care. The global gap in access to engineering and technology is significant and prevents individuals and communities from meeting their development needs and living lives of opportunity.
Engineers Without Borders Australia is addressing this gap by connecting, educating and empowering people through humanitarian engineering - a community-centred approach to engineering design and practice. EWB has ten years' experience delivering international and domestic programs in partnership with community organisations, engineering companies, universities and government.
Lizzie Brown, EWB's CEO, will provide insights into the organisation's impact through a series of case studies. She will share her vision of EWB over the next ten years and identify opportunities for students, professionals and engineering companies to increase their social legacy and help engineer a better world.

item.title: EMERALD HILL FESTIVAL: ONE DAY STREET PARTY
item.description:
Multicultural Arts Victoria is thrilled to co-present the Emerald Hill Festival, a free annual one day street party featuring diverse artistic talent, food and activities on Sunday 9 November from 11am-4pm, organised in collaboration with our creative neighbours in the Emerald Hill precinct in South Melbourne. The festival spans western classical music to Burundian drumming, Polynesian dance, Japanese Shamisen and everything in between, alongside the opportunity to taste a global feast from a range of Melbourne’s iconic food trucks. Adults and children are also invited to participate in a range of art and music activities offered through the day. Multicultural Arts Victoria has programmed a diverse range of energetic and enthralling performances and interactive activities throughout the day including:Kundalila, Rosario De Marco, Noriko Tadano, Nuholani, Burundian Drumming Group, Byron and the Gypsy Cats, Dani Sib, Vinod Prasanna
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

ns0:venue.name: Bank St & Perrins St, South Melbourne

image.altText: EMERALD HILL FESTIVAL: ONE DAY STREET PARTY
EMERALD HILL FESTIVAL: ONE DAY STREET PARTY

item.title: Docklands History Group
item.description:
Travel back in time with local historians, collectors, guest speakers and meet like-minded people at the monthly Docklands History Group. November's special guest speaker is Carmel Taig who will talk about her new book 'The Giant by the River: A History of the Yarraville Sugar Works'.
Share a cuppa and stories with other local history enthusiasts and learn about the people, places and industries from times gone by.
The group meets on the fourth Thursday of the month and everyone is welcome.

item.title: Diabetes Australia Walk to Work Day
item.description:
The annual Diabetes Australia Walk to Work Day, now in its 17th year, aims to get Australians walking regularly and encourages employees and employers to build regular walking into their daily routines.
Participants can register for free and are encouraged to set a goal for the six-week campaign, including walking one kilometre on Walk to Work Day, hosting a healthy breakfast and walking more throughout every work day.
Research of 400,000 people has found that walking an extra 15 minutes each day can help extend life expectancy by up to three years, while reducing the risk of stroke, heart disease and type II diabetes as well as increasing mental well-being.
The campaign will finish with celebrations on Friday 14 November 2014, which marks Diabetes Australia Walk to Work Day and World Diabetes Day.

image.altText: Diabetes Australia Walk to Work Day
Diabetes Australia Walk to Work Day

item.title: Design Commissions for Creative Cities
item.description:
In this MPavilion collaboration with support from the National Gallery of Victoria, Ben Evans, Director of the London Design Festival, will discuss his latest festival and exhibition program, the commissioning of temporary design projects, London's position as a design capital and the festival's impact on London's cultural identity. Can Melbourne learn any lessons from London's experience?
Ben will also be in conversation with Dr Ann Stephen, Senior Curator, University Art Gallery and Art Collection, The University of Sydney. Join in with your own questions.
The London Design Festival was established in 2003 as an annual event to celebrate and promote London as the creative capital of the world. The festival acts as a platform for partner organisations drawn from across the design community to stage the UK's biggest annual design event.
The London Design Festival has commissioned leading designers and architects to create interventions in London's public spaces during the festival, often pairing the designers with manufacturers who are exploring new materials or processes. The festival also collaborates annually with the V&A Museum.
With an eye to such an interventionist approach, and the successful Temporary Serpentine Pavilion, the Naomi Milgrom Foundation has boldly commissioned the inaugural MPavilion, designed by architect Sean Godsell.
With increasing interest in design and architecture, are conditions right for our own Melbourne Design Festival?
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: City Sessions Vol.4
item.description:
City Sessions is an interactive dance battle presented by Freestyle Academy and supported by City of Melbourne through Arts Grant 2014.
Enjoy some of Australia's best dancers and performances by Melbourne DJs, MCs and street artists.
The event will start at the State Library and travel through to Federation Square for the final battle.

item.title: BioBlitz Flora Fitzroy Gardens
item.description:
Come along on a walking tour of Fitzroy Gardens and help record the different types of vegetation, from mosses and lichens to the giant Queensland Kauri tree. These surveys will all be led by a range of flora experts from The Royal Botanic Gardens and RMIT.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help us to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Over two weeks from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from miniscule plant life to the mighty Powerful Owl, and we need your help. You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony or laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?
Presented by Urban Landscapes @ City of Melbourne.

item.title: Barriers to Education
item.description:
Explore an interactive installation that uncovers the world's greatest challenges to education, in the Swanston St Forecourt of Federation Square.
Barriers to Education is a school-based initiative of Save the Children Australia. The program focuses on education as a fundamental right of all children and highlights the key barriers to learning for children around the world.

item.title: Anatolian Festival 2014
item.description:
The Anatolian Festival is a celebration of the coming together of communities, with outdoor stalls of food and merchandise, street theatre and entertainment, cultural performances, arts and crafts, and information booths from both the Turkish and mainstream community groups.
The Anatolian Festival presents a wide range of cultural activities to celebrate the Anatolian community, and aims to facilitate unity, harmony and diversity in Melbourne’s multicultural society, in a safe and risk-free environment.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Mornington Christmas Market
item.description:
As Christmas is quickly sneaking up, it is time to start thinking about purchasing presents for your loved ones. Make sure you come down to Main Street Mornington for the Christmas Market. The street will be filled with music, laughter and exciting new stallholders. From 6pm Mornington Park will come alive with the annual Mornington Carols in the Park featuring local schools and performers.
Everyone wants to purchase something special and unique for their family and friends, so why not think about shopping handmade this Christmas? The stallholders will line the street showcasing their lovingly crafted and grown products, and if you can't find the perfect present why not speak to the stallholder to see if they can create a one off for you?
At the market you can find fashion and accessories to wear during the festive season, gorgeous new toys for the kids, Christmas decorations for your home and of course lots of fresh produce to enjoy cooking with. So whether you are looking for an original gift for a friend, child or something for yourself, the Main Street Market is the place to find it.
To apply to become a stallholder please email operator or visit their website to download the stallholder application form.

item.title: Vinyl Lounge at the MPavilion
item.description:
This December Melbourne vinyl lovers will gather at MPavilion on to enjoy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia's Vinyl Lounge.
Already an institution in Canberra, the Vinyl Lounge sees the NFSA's sound gurus Thorsten Kaeding and Graham McDonald play rare and fascinating records from the national collection, and gives the audience a chance to share (and show off) some of their own vinyl. And it's free!
This will be the second time the National Film and Sound Archive takes its turntables outside of Canberra, following a special sold out session at the Sydney Opera House Studio in October.
Melburnians shouldn't miss this chance to enjoy music the way it was meant to be heard, in the relaxed atmosphere of MPavilion.
MPavilion is a unique architecture commission and design event for Melbourne, initiated by the Naomi Milgrom Foundation with support from City of Melbourne and the Victorian State Government. It is located in the Queen Victoria Gardens, in the centre of the Southbank Arts Precint.

item.title: From the Prom to the Port
item.description:
From the Prom to the Port is an exhibition by well know local Port Albert artist Warren Curry.
The exhibition will showcase Warren's latest Oil Paintings from locations from Wilsons Promontory to Port Albert.
For more information please contact the Port Albert Art Gallery.

item.title: Sticks Sunday Sessions
item.description:
Rock into Sticks Yarra Valley every Sunday over summer and chill out with some cool tunes and a glass of your favourite wine.
Featuring live music on the lawn stage and a gourmet sausage sizzle on the deck, it's the perfect day out.
Entry is free, however please call the cellar door to reserve a table!

item.title: Brimbank Sustainable Living Expo
item.description:
Brimbank Sustainable Living Expo will showcase food, health and wellbeing demonstrations, how to reduce your waste going to landfill, sustainability from garden to plate and how to make gardening a social activity.
Learn from the experts in short DIY sessions, meet native animals and farm babies and see a community garden in full swing. There will be recycled art activities and planting activities for the kids, a clothes swap, a recycled book giveaway and lots of information sessions.

item.title: New Year's Eve at Fed Square
item.description:
Light up and shine this New Year's Eve with a colourful spectacle at Fed Square.
African beats, samba dance, circus acts and neon lights, Fed Square's free New Year's Eve celebrations will be a party to remember. Reflecting the rich cultural diversity of Melbourne, The Square will illuminate in a kaleidoscope of colour and so will you! Wear your brightest colours or crystal whites so you illuminate under a canopy of ultraviolet lights installed exclusively for the celebration.
Experience the big beats of Lamine Sonko and African Intelligence as they guide you through easy dance steps that, on the stroke of midnight, will coalesce in an en-masse dance to their popular track, Light and Shine. The entertainment lineup also includes Sounds of Polynesia, Marawa the Amazing, Ethiopian Circus Trio, Maracatu Estrela do Mar featuring Neda Rahmani and Samba Dancers, Wassawumba and Congo Tardis #1.

image.altText: New Year's Eve at Fed Square
New Year's Eve at Fed Square

item.title: Emerald Hill Festival
item.description:
Multicultural Arts Victoria is thrilled to co-present the Emerald Hill Festival, a free annual one day street party featuring diverse artistic talent, food and activities. The Emerald Hill Festival is organised in collaboration with the creative neighbours in the Emerald Hill precinct in South Melbourne.
The festival spans western classical music to Burundian drumming, Polynesian dance, Japanese Shamisen and everything in between, alongside the opportunity to taste a global feast from a range of Melbourne's iconic food trucks. Adults and children are also invited to participate in a range of art and music activities offered through the day.

item.title: Risky Business- Managing Risk at your events
item.description:
The City of Port Phillip is hosting Risky Business, a free information session. The seminar is aimed at anyone organising an event whether it be big or small event; community event, school fair, sporting or local trader event.
By attending the event seminar you will discover the importance of risk management. Key discussion will include: what is risk, identifying risk, understanding implementing and developing a risk plan, writing an emergency response plan and managing risk in this changing landscape.
This event is free and will be held on Wednesday 19 November at Council Chambers St Kilda Town Hall from 5.30pm to 7.30pm.

address.address1: Corner Carlisle Street and Brighton Road St Kilda

image.altText: Risky Business- Managing Risk at your events
Risky Business- Managing Risk at your events

item.title: BioBlitz Westgate Park Dawn Bird Chorus
item.description:
Start the day with a walking bird survey of Westgate Park – experience the intense and beautiful dawn bird chorus, and learn from leading experts about the variety of beautiful birds in this park.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help us to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne’s best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony, laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?
Presented by Urban Landscapes @ City of Melbourne.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Tongue Between Teeth – Book Launch
item.description:
Jessica Knight's first collection of poetry, 'Tongue Between Teeth', will be welcomed into the world with cheap drinks and homemade cupcakes in the lovely Westspace art gallery.
'Tongue Between Teeth' will be available for purchase on the night and Jessica will be signing copies. Come for the poetry, stay for the cupcakes.
Supported by Creative Partnerships Australia.

item.title: Technology and Mythology
item.description:
Technology and Mythology is an exhibition by artist Joseph Flynn that explores technology, mythology and iconography in a post-internet age.
In the exhibition, the artist explores the merging of two different ideas of what the word 'icon' lends itself to, both in a technological sense as a way of art-making and an attempt to understand ancient mythologies.

item.title: Sunshine on the Super Il-legitimate
item.description:
Sunshine on the Super Il-legitimate is the latest exhibition by Melbourne-based artist, Jacqui Shelton.
Jacqui has recently had solo shows at West Space and Substation Gallery, and has an upcoming show at BUS Projects. She was included in Moving Pictures/Expanding Space at CareOf in Milan and Experimental Congress at Gertrude Contemporary and will be undertaking residencies at NARS Artist Foundation (New York) and PICA (Perth) in 2015.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Something Happened
item.description:
Something Happened is a series of documented performances by Melbourne- and Perth-based artists Ross Coulter, Hannah Jackson, Tanya Lee and Stuart Ringholt. These videos capture absurd situations that explore boundaries between discomfort, fear, embarrassment and displacement. Recalling the absurdist tradition, these works straddle a line between humiliation and humour, depicting actions performed in both public and private settings.
Curated by Chelsea Hopper.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Small Business & Party Plan Showcase
item.description:
This event is the newest market located in Taylors Lakes, and supports the local small business owners and party plan representatives, both locally and through Melbourne and Surrounds
Stalls Include, Personalized Products, Jewellery, Children's Clothing & Décor, Women's Accessories, Handmade Arts and Crafts, Home Wares and Home Décor, Beauty and Skincare Products, Perfume, Candles & Soaps, Kids party Ideas and Loads More.
And For the Kids there will be a jumping castle, face painting & arts and crafts

item.title: Royal Park Schools BioBlitz
item.description:
Come along to a Royal Park BioBlitz to undertake a variety of surveys including insects, reptiles and plants with our City of Melbourne Park Rangers, Zoos Victoria and other experts.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz and help discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony, laneway or street by sharing images.
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?

item.title: BioBlitz Royal Park Dawn Bird Chorus
item.description:
Start the day with an exhilarating walking bird survey of Royal Park. Experience the dawn bird chorus and hear from leading experts on the variety of beautiful birds that visit this park - you'll be surprised and delighted!
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help us to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony or laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?
Presented by Urban Landscapes @ City of Melbourne.

item.title: Project Genesis: Hip Hop and Gospel
item.description:
Multicultural Arts Victoria presents Genesis - a sensational line up of young hip hop musicians and gospel singers.
Genesis is the brainchild of Fostin Nshimirimana, from The Movement. For the past six months Fostin has been collaborating with emerging hip hop and gospel artists from Shepparton and Melbourne, uncovering diverse stories from some of their refugee backgrounds and generating new music and new connections between artists in metro Melbourne and regional Victoria.

image.altText: Project Genesis: Hip Hop and Gospel
Project Genesis: Hip Hop and Gospel

item.title: Poppy Crafting Group at Library at The Dock
item.description:
Collaborate with other crafters to help create poppies for the 2015 ANZAC Centenary celebrations at the Melbourne Library Service.
Poppies will be placed on display at all branches as part of the centenary commemoration.
Please bring your preferred crafting materials. Crochet and knitted patterns will be available.
The event wil run on the first Friday of the month from 2pm to 4pm.

item.title: Places for People? Seminar
item.description:
Knowing how a city works as a place for people is crucial to carefully guiding its sustainable growth and ongoing sustainability.
Through urban analysis and in-the-field surveys, Places for People has generated a decade-by-decade snapshot of the conditions defining the public environment and how public space is used by people. This research has allowed Places for People to monitor and examine how the city is changing.
Join them in a seminar where they will share some of the research learnings with you, and where you will gain detailed insights on city-shaping influences as observed by us.
Places are limited so please register your interest.
To become part of our city shaping journey: -Visit the MKW Hub to share your thoughts, and gain a detailed insight on city shaping influences as observed by us. -Share your thoughts online.
This event is presented by City of Melbourne.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

address.address2: and Swanston Street, Melbourne Town Hall

item.title: Nocturnal Insect Bioblitz Royal Park
item.description:
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help the team discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Get up close and personal with the nocturnal insects of Royal Park in the darkest late-night biodiversity you'll experience in the city. During these surveys experts will use lights, traps and nets to identify the insects inhabiting the gardens.
Over two weeks from 31 October to 15 November, the City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty Powerful Owl, and we need your help. You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony or laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb)
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home? Find out more and register at the event website.
Presented by Urban Landscapes at the City of Melbourne.

item.title: Moral Principlism: Formulating Non–Religious Ethics
item.description:
The Atheist Society is hosting a public lecture on 'Moral Principlism: Formulating Non-Religious Ethics' with Dr John Perkins from the Secular Party of Australia at the Unitarian Hall. The lecture will be followed by questions and discussion.
The Atheist Society is for atheists, agnostics and free thinkers who agree to disagree.

item.title: Melbourne BioBlitz at the Knowledge Hub
item.description:
Did you know that Melbourne is home to more than 1,800 plant and over 500 animal species?
From 31 October to 15 November 2014, the City of Melbourne is running their first BioBlitz and they need your help!
During Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 you can help them discover some of the diverse animal and plant species that call the city home. Participants will be able to work alongside experts to discover Melbourne's biodiversity and help them produce a list of species living within the municipality, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl.
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call the city home. Take part by sharing images using the hashtag #bioblitzmelb, online, or by joining a guided BioBlitz event.
At the Melbourne Knowledge Week Hub between 27-31 October, you will be able to talk to the volunteers, find out more information about how to do your own survey and register for one of their events.
The information collected during Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 will inform the City of Melbourne's Urban Ecology Strategy.
This event is presented by City of Melbourne and partners.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

address.address1: Corner Little Collins and Swanston Street

item.title: Marise Maas – Trying Not To Worry
item.description:
Examining Marise Maas' paintings is like peering into a series of little precarious worlds - each bearing the trace of some implicit, destabilising truth. Here, roof tiles are formed from haphazard lines; windows float up and away from their foundational structures; houses teeter on disjointed stilts; electricity pylons and cranes tilt ever so slightly. On a domestic scale, small inert objects such as bowls, take-away containers or coffee cups, stack and tumble off flat slopes of colour, losing any gravitational connection to their once intended utility.
This selection of seemingly mundane motifs in her exhibition Trying Not to Worry holds very real significance for Maas. Informed by what she describes as the bubble of her own local surroundings and domestic family life, the act of painting serves as a kind of diaristic process through which the comprehension, or perhaps apprehension, of daily life takes place.
Items from the kitchen table, backyard or local sports oval all become potential vehicles for the expression of the private logic of her thoughts and fragmentary connections. Honest feelings of anxiety, consternation or whim are allowed to distort the concrete actuality of her subjects, giving rise to a potentially cryptic collection of amusing, somewhat ambiguous narratives.

image.altText: Marise Maas – Trying Not To Worry
Marise Maas – Trying Not To Worry

item.title: Lumen
item.description:
Australia's leading contemporary street artist, Rone, returns to Melbourne for Lumen, his first solo Australian exhibition in over two years.
Lumen includes 11 large-scale portraits inside and outside of the gallery and a 12-metre-high mural on the building's adjoining ventilation tower.
The space itself - an abandoned office building slated for demolition - has been transformed into a black (and blank) canvas for the artist to take over. Internally, the artworks will be brought spectacularly to life by lighting designer, John McKissock.

item.title: Just a Girl
item.description:
This exhibition is a portrayal of the moments in artist Gabrielle Savrone's life where she was uncomfortable or told no, simply because she is female.
Says Gabrielle, 'Abstraction allows the viewer to complete the image in their mind. This brings them into the work with me and creates a moment in time, a completion of the art that does not exist without the viewer'.
This exhibition is a mixed media interactive and visual exploration which combines installation, print and photography as well as acrylic and oil paint.
Gabrielle will donate ten per cent all sales to the Victorian Immigrant and Refugee Women's Coalition.

item.title: Homebuyers Seminar
item.description:
The free Homebuyers Seminar will present professional advice on how to choose the right home for you, the current property market, relevant laws and more. You will have the opportunity to meet and hear from all the experts as they provide an outline of where and how to buy in the Melbourne marketplace.
In addition to experts from the REIV, speakers from Consumer Affairs Victoria and the Law Institute of Victoria will also offer advice tailored to help you buy a home with confidence

item.title: Gallipoli with Peter Fitzsimons
item.description:
The story of the Anzacs at Gallipoli is an important part of Australia's national identity. In the lead-up to the centenary of Anzac, join one of Australia's leading author's Peter FitzSimons as he explores the story of the Anzacs in his new book Gallipoli.
Australia's biggest-selling non-fiction author of the last 10 years, Peter FitzSimons is the author of over 20 books, including Tobruk, Kokoda, Batavia, Mawson and the Ice Men of the Heroic Age, Ned Kelly and biographies of Nancy Wake' Kim Beazley' Nick Farr-Jones' Les Darcy, Steve Waugh and John Eales. He was named a Member of the Order of Australia for his services to literature and the community, and is a journalist with the Sydney Morning Herald and Sun-Herald.

item.title: Forex Trading Workshop
item.description:
While the volatile global market has investors tearing their hair out, Greg Secker will show you why savvy currency traders on the foreign exchange market are making huge profits day after day, no matter whether the markets are rising or falling. Greg is one of the World's leading currency traders and coaches.
In just a couple of hours at his free workshop, Financial Freedom through Forex, he will teach you his secrets to what he believes is. The fastest and easiest way to make a fortune in the world today.
At this free event workshop Greg will teach you:
- How 30 minutes of daily trading can help build a sustainable secondary income Fast - The discipline that means you never risk more than 1% of your capital - 3 simple but incredibly powerful strategies that he uses every day - Why you should be part of the world's largest and most liquid market ($4 trillion a day) - How to automate everything - set up, walk away and collect profits at the end of the day - How trading is something you can do at home or anywhere - How an easy second income can be your primary income - How it's possible to create passive income that makes you money while you sleep - And much more - you choose, the control is in your hands
Secure your free seat now, and set yourself on a course to financial freedom.

item.title: Fitzroy Gardens BioBlitz Discovery!
item.description:
Take a walking tour and discover the resident wildlife, such as reptiles, bugs, bees and butterflies. These surveys will be led by a range of fauna experts from Museum Victoria, the Australian Research Centre for Urban Ecology and RMIT. Jump on a tour leaving on the hour, every hour.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help discover the diverse animal and plant species that call Melbourne city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony, laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?

item.title: Fitzroy Gardens BioBlitz
item.description:
Take a walking tour and discover the resident wildlife, such as bugs, bees and butterflies. These surveys will be led by a range of fauna experts from Museum Victoria, RMIT and the University of Melbourne. Tours will leave on the hour, every hour until 3pm.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help discover the diverse animal and plant species that call Melbourne home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony or laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?

item.title: BioBlitz Fitzroy Gardens Dawn Bird Chorus
item.description:
Start the day with a walking bird survey of Fitzroy Gardens, experience the dawn bird chorus and hear from leading experts on the variety of beautiful birds that visit our parks.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help us to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony or laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?
Presented by Urban Landscapes @ City of Melbourne.

item.title: Dancing with Death
item.description:
The first in a series of exhibitions presented by 2013 RAW Melbourne Visual Artist of the Year, Rehgan De Mather, Dancing with Death explores influences from recent travels to Mexico and South America, including the Day of the Dead and Carnival.
Opening night features a performance by contemporary dancer Kelly Way and includes the book launch for Dancing with Death, a selection of studio shots and images documenting the progress and process of the new work.

item.title: Cloaked Combat 2, 3
item.description:
Steaphan Paton's Cloaked Combat series is a visual exploration of the material and technological conflicts between cultures, and the roles they play in one culture asserting dominance over another.
A juxtaposition of historical and modern technologies, Cloaked Combat 2 and 3 highlight an uneven match between two warring cultures and the brutality of European invasion/colonisation in Australia.
Steaphan Paton is an interdisciplinary artist based in Melbourne. A member of the Gunai Nation, his practice explores tradition, race and colonialism informed through his worldview of being Aboriginal Australian.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Christopher Jewitt presents The Lovers
item.description:
Melbourne artist Christopher Jewitt presents an epic suite of large scale paintings, including a 10m work, in Eckersley's exhibition space.
In this series, Jewitt focuses on concepts of love and sex. Figures are portrayed in bursts of intuitive patterns, limbs are entangled in sprays of colour and movement. Jewitt suggests a range of human emotions expressed by the human figure, most particularly the invisible but strong bonds between people.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: BioBlitz Aboriginal Heritage Walk
item.description:
Journey into the ancestral lands of the Kulin Nation, discover the connection between biodiversity and Australia's Aboriginal people, and explore their rich and thriving culture on this walk in the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne. Experience a traditional smoking ceremony with an Aboriginal guide and discover traditional uses of plants for food, tools and medicine.
Then, why not take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014? Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, the City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help. Join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city, led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists, and help us to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: BioBlitz Fitzroy Gardens BatBlitz
item.description:
Discover the different bat species living in Fitzroy Gardens in this late-night event. During these surveys, experts will use traps and recording devices to identify the different types of bats in the gardens.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help scientists to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home. Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne’s best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
