The International Specialised Skills Institute (ISS Institute) fellowships are designed to allow enterprising Australians to study innovations, technologies and best practice techniques overseas and bring these back to Australia. The program also brings international experts to Australia. This combination provides a unique approach to addressing the challenges faced by Australian industry in upskilling its workforce and remaining competitive in a changing global environment.
This event is brought to you by the International Specialised Skills Institute as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Is There a Future for Manufacturing in Australia?
item.description:
Challenges to the Australian manufacturing sector have never been greater. Increased global competition, technological innovation and a strong economy have threatened the existence of many Australian organisations. While these conditions may prove difficult for some firms, there remain many niche areas of operation and strategy in which Australian organisations can specialise to ensure they remain sustainably profitable and successful in the global market.
Improving the quality of leadership in Australian workplaces is often a neglected issue in the debate on competitiveness. This public lecture will investigate the role of leadership in shaping and driving Australia's transition to a high-value manufacturing economy. Keynote speaker John Pollaers, Chair of the Australian Advanced Manufacturing Council, will be joined by a panel of experts in a one-hour exploratory discussion of how leadership roles and techniques will impact the future of manufacturing in Australia.
John Pollaers has an extensive leadership background in the manufacturing sector, as the former Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director of Pacific Brands. John was Chief Executive Officer of Foster's Group Limited from May 2011, after joining the company as Managing Director of Carlton & United Breweries in 2010. John's distinguished career also encompasses experience in consumer products. His senior roles at Diageo plc included President Asia Pacific and Managing Director Australasia, where he was also a member of the Diageo Group Executive Committee. John's career has been marked by repeated turnaround performances in which he has successfully led nine business transformations, Pacific Brands' being the most recent.
This event is presented by the Centre for Workplace Leadership as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: Sidney Myer Asia Centre, University of Melbourne

item.title: How Stuff Gets to Melbourne
item.description:
Have you ever wondered what happens in the Port of Melbourne? Who works there, why the cranes are so big, or how we developed the waterways to bring the everyday goods we use to Melbourne?
Andrea Fleming (CEO, Mission to Seafarers) and John Bennett (General Manager, Bid Management, Port of Melbourne Corporation) will discuss the history, present and future of the value of the waterways.
This event is presented by the Mission to Seafarers and The Port of Melbourne Corporation.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Hack It
item.description:
Hack It is a unique workshop for high school students who want to turn their creative ideas into software and apps that can make a difference to the world.
Hack It will challenge students to create an app that solves a real problem facing the City of Melbourne. Whether you're an aspiring developer, social activist or entrepreneur, this is your chance to try coding for a day in a fun environment supported by researchers from NICTA and Melbourne universities. After a presentation setting the scene, you'll be split into assigned groups with a mix of different skills. Each group will brainstorm ideas, pick one to bring to life, create a demo and then pitch it to the full group and a panel of experts. The groups will be supported by NICTA researchers and software engineers, with prizes offered for the best pitch and best hack.
NICTA is Australia's largest information and communications technology (ICT) research and development centre. It pursues high-impact, original research that is inspired by real-world challenges. NICTA is also the national coordinating body for the Digital Careers program and a critical training ground for future ICT researchers.
This event is presented by NICTA and Digital Careers.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Grasslands
item.description:
Grasslands is a living installation that gathers over 10,000 indigenous plants. This organic composition aims to recreate the vast grass plains that stretched over the State Library of Victoria site before it was established in the mid-nineteenth century.
Linda Tegg conceived of this site-specific project during her 2012 Georges Mora Foundation Fellowship at the State Library of Victoria. Researching the original flora of this site, the artist found that most available data was interpretative, from Victorian landscape paintings to illustrated maps.
Looking to expand her sources of knowledge, Tegg collaborated with horticulturist John Delpratt and the University of Melbourne to source, grow and nurture the 10,000 indigenous plants and grasses that make up Grasslands.
The result is a transformation of history and nature by artistic imagination, inviting us to visualise the layers of memory and place.
This project has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australia Council, its arts funding and advisory body and the Victorian Government through Arts Victoria. Grasslands has also been supported by the City of Melbourne through the Arts Grant Program.
This project is supported by University of Melbourne - Burnley Campus, Department of Resource Management and Geography. Grasslands is the result of a Georges Mora Foundation Fellowship at the State Library of Victoria.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Going Virtual: The Arrival of the Internet
item.description:
It is a quarter-century since the University of Melbourne brought the Internet to Australia. At that time, it was seen as little more than a useful tool for computing professionals. So, what is the Internet?
A communications medium, a knowledge machine, a virtual universe? Professor Justin Zobel, Head of the University of Melbourne's Department of Computing and Information Systems, and a staff member in the Department during the years leading up to the Internet's arrival, will reflect on the Internet's evolution and impact. The talk will cover the concepts and ambitions that came together to create it to the emergence of an all-pervading technology that is dramatically changing - and challenging - how we work, play, learn, and think.
Professor Justin Zobel received his PhD from the University of Melbourne and for many years was based at RMIT University, where he led the Search Engine group. He is now Head of the Department of Computing and Information Systems at the University of Melbourne.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week.

item.title: Free Activities at Fitness First During Fitness Week
item.description:
Celebrate Fitness Week at Fitness First! Whatever your fitness level, come along and participate in a fantastic range of free daily themed activities, including group exercise classes, freestyle group training, workshops and advice.
Each day of Fitness Week will focus on a different area of fitness, from strength training and dynamic movement training to mind/body workshops involving Pilates and yoga, and the importance of recovery and wellness.

item.title: For King and Country
item.description:
East Melbourne Historical Society presents an exhibition commemorating the service of East Melbourne citizens in the First World War. Though only a small suburb, during the war there were over 770 service people with some connection - birth, work, housing - to East Melbourne.
This is one of the fun activities taking place across the City of Melbourne's library branches during History Week, 19 to 26 October.

item.title: Finding families
item.description:
Enter the intriguing world of genealogy and learn how to start building your family tree in this free introductory workshop for beginners.
Librarians from the Family History team will introduce the key principles of family history research, show you how to access and use a range of resources, and take you on a tour of the Library's Family History collection.

item.title: Exploring the Potentials of Virtual Reality
item.description:
Back in the '80s and '90s, Virtual Reality (VR) meant donning a headset and grasping at things that only you could see. VR as pure entertainment was the stuff of the super-gamer and was as limited in its appeal as its accessibility. In 2013, Oculus Rift released a headset available to the general consumer for under $500 and, not long after, Facebook acquired Oculus for $2billion.
Part of the unmasking of virtual reality has been its application to real-world needs - architectural walk-throughs, simulations, training - which is where the GEElab can show you the potentials of virtual reality. Join four GEElab experts and their guests as they take you through how (not) to build a VR game, how to use VR for architectural visualisation, serious games, and how to implement VR in Unity and Unreal Engine version 4. Games will also be playable at the session. Bookings essential.
This event is presented by RMIT University Games and Experimental Entertainment Lab (GEElab) as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Dive into the Penguin Pool
item.description:
Named after Arup's first project - The Penguin Pool at London Zoo - this global creative event series aims to encourage new connections and seed future collaborations across the design community.
Arup is a leading design engineering firm that has played a key part in some of the world's finest and most famous buildings. From the Sydney Opera House to the Beijing Water Cube, Arup is a firm that continues to innovate within their discipline. Known for lateral thinking, they host The Penguin Pool annually to connect their firm with designers, creatives and artists.
The last Penguin Pool was held at Federation Square's Deakin Edge, with whom Arup collaborated with on the event. It asked artists to reimagine Melbourne and present work on how it might be improved. Four Melbourne Knowledge Week artists involved in past events, along with Arup, will share their thoughts and experiences collaborating with one another. Drinks and nibbles will be provided. Bring an open mind to new connections and ideas!
This event is presented by Arup.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Discover Sailing Day
item.description:
Discover Sailing is an initiative that gives people the opportunity to try sailing free of charge. Along with the assistance of Yachting Victoria, yacht clubs around the state will welcome the public to experience the joys of the sailing lifestyle.
In 2014/15, over 60 clubs will participate, exceeding the 2013/14 figure of 54 clubs.
Get down to the Docklands Yacht Club or a yacht club near you and give sailing a go.

item.title: Discover Europe Travel Expo
item.description:
The Discover Europe Travel Expo is in town, providing tips on exclusive deals for Europe-bound travellers looking to bag a bargain for a 2015 holiday.
The free expo offers expert advice, exclusive savings and everything travellers need to plan, compare and book under the one roof. Europe's leading travel providers and holiday specialists will unveil their earlybird offers and new products for 2015.
Participating airlines include Qantas, Malaysia and Singapore airlines, as well as tour operators including Trafalgar, Globus, APT, Topdeck, Scenic Tours, Contiki and Insight Vacations.
Experienced travel consultants from Flight Centre, Escape Travel, Student Flights and Cruiseabout will also be available to assist customers with their travel plans and take bookings on the day.

item.title: Designing Science
item.description:
Accurately designed biomedical animations can aid the understanding of researchers, displaying processes otherwise unseen by the human eye. 3D printers means rapid prototyping and ever-changing designs are easily incorporated.
In this panel discussion, explore design principles used in the animation of scientific knowledge to educate and entertain, in 3D titanium printing, molecule design and in science-inspired art.
This event is presented by CSIRO.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI)

item.title: Contemporary Outsider Art Conference
item.description:
More than fifty artists, curators, educators and researchers from around the world will gather at the inaugural Contemporary Outsider Art Conference, presented by Arts Project Australia and the University of Melbourne, to discuss and debate the role and place of Outsider Art in a contemporary global context.
Since the late 19th century Outsider Art, also known as art brut or naive art, has referred to art made by the untrained or uneducated, those who exist outside the parameters of the traditional art world and, in particular, those who create art through the prism of mental illness, marginalisation or social exclusion.
The conference program of free keynote addresses, paper sessions and panel discussions will focus on the practices of Outsider Artists, collecting and curating Outsider Art and Outsider Art history and theory.
This conference is free and open to all.

item.title: Compass Market
item.description:
A day into the right, where brand new and unique individual artists, designers from Melbourne coming and showcasing together.
South meets North, East meets West.
Be sure to be widely entertained and inspired. From beautiful sound to your ear that will make you dance as you shop the very fine gifts from the collective creative beings. Amuse your wonder-last by our fashion catwalk, which will take place twice during the event.

item.title: Collaborative Knowledge Creation
item.description:
Join us to learn about collaboration as a tool to create new knowledge across social, industry and disciplinary boundaries - now and in the future.
Collabforge will explore methods of collaboration with 20-60 participants through a digitally-enhanced interactive workshop that demonstrates knowledge transfer and knowledge co-creation in real time. The session will be introduced and framed with a brief presentation of case studies from some of Collabforge's many knowledge-focused collaboration projects.
Presented by Collabforge.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: City Road – Melbourne's First Road Walking Tour
item.description:
Before European settlement, Melbourne's indigenous inhabitants walked a common path from the Yarra to the coast, arriving at what we now call Sandridge Beach. From 1835, Europeans followed this path which became known as Sandridge Road, Melbourne's first road. Today we know it as City Road.
Come along for a walk to learn the history of City Road, its importance, its industrial architecture, Melbourne's tallest buildings and the current City Road Master Plan.
This is one of the activities taking place across the City of Melbourne's library branches during History Week, 19-26 October.

item.title: Children's Week Art Exhibition
item.description:
The City of Melbourne's Children's and Family Services Team is celebrating Children's Week with an annual art exhibition, featuring inspiring artwork created by children and families attending City of Melbourne Children's Services and Family Services programs.
This year, Children's Services and Family Services will come together with a special art exhibition under the one theme: The right of the child to speak and be heard. The theme is taken from the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.

item.title: Bruno Leti – Landscapes of the Soul
item.description:
The Museo Italiano hosts an exhibition of Bruno Leti's work revisiting some fifty years of art-making.
Leti is represented in major Australian national, state and regional galleries and in public and private collections internationally. His art has also been the object of several monographs by leading art historians. Since his emigration from Italy in 1952, Bruno's Italianness has grown as an essential component of his artistic inspiration, nurtured by his childhood memories, by his studies in art history, by his frequent journeys to his native country and by an ongoing engagement with Italian art and literature.
Leti has travelled and worked widely in Europe, America and Asia, drawing inspiration from very diverse natural and cultural landscapes. Bruno describes himself as an Australian artist and indeed the multiculturalism and cosmopolitanism to which Bruno has made a signal contribution in the world of art, are by now quintessentially Australian traits.
The exhibition will be launched by Sir James Gobbo, and guest speaker Professor Sasha Grishin (Australian National University) will introduce the exhibition.

item.title: Boisterous Beginnings: Early Doctors in Victoria
item.description:
This exhibition examines the early beginnings of the Port Phillip Medical Association (PPMA),highlighting the key individuals and social values of the day.
From 1830s, doctors began their work in the Port Phillip District. There were some formidable personalities practising medicine in the area at the time, but they often had other interests and activities that were apparently more important: politics, for example, or the acquisition of land and the accumulation of fortune. This exhibition explores the people of this medical association.
This event is presented by the Medical History Museum.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Bilas Body Adornment
item.description:
Drawing upon body adornment techniques and designs from Pacific culture, visual artist Lisa Hilli works with particpants to create unique woven pieces to 'bilas' or adorn and decorate your body.
Utilising a mixture of contemporary everyday materials and Pacific weaving techniques, Lisa shares her passion and skill of weaving in a supportive studio environment.
This weaving workshop is aimed for young people aged 13 to 25 years. Previous weaving skills an advantage but not necessary.

item.title: Big Ideas Under the Dome: Elizabeth Broderick
item.description:
In this Big Ideas Under the Dome series lecture, Elizabeth Broderick, Australia's Sex Discrimination Commissioner, speaks on the status of gender equality in Australia. The 30-minute talk will be followed by Q&A with Jill Singer.
Elizabeth has acted as Sex Discrimination Commissioner since 2007, and was also the Commissioner responsible for Age Discrimination from 2007 to 2011. She has been a key advocate for Australia's national paid parental leave scheme and domestic violence reform, and is Global Co-Chair of the Women's Empowerment Principles Leadership Group, a joint initiative of the UN Global Compact and UN Women.

item.title: Big Bang Sounds
item.description:
How is new knowledge impacting the creative imaginations of today? This conversation will take you into the depths of the Big Bang and back again.
Lawrence Harvey, Associate Professor and Director SIAL Sound Studios, RMIT University, ventures into the unknown with Dr Katie Mack and artist Abel Korinsky to discuss new findings and theories related to the Big Bang. Can the Big Bang be seen and heard today? What place does it hold in scientific and artistic discourse?
Abel Korinsky from the Korinsky Art Collective (Germany) is currently in residence with Experimenta at RMIT Project Space, supported by EMARE (European Media Art Residency Exchange). Working with multichannel sound installations, Korinsky questions what could happen if sounds from the past could be reconstructed and hearable again.
Dr Katherine (Katie) Mack is a theoretical astrophysicist. Her work focuses on finding new ways to learn about the early universe and fundamental physics using astronomical observations, probing the building blocks of nature by examining the cosmos on the largest scales.
This event is presented by Experimenta.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Be a Composer!
item.description:
Join this three-day interactive music composition and performance workshop with Ben Opie, Melissa Doecke and Phoebe Green. The workshops culminate in a piece that is developed with participants throughout the week. Learn about the creative process, new techniques, commissioning new works and collaborating with artists.
Join Inventi Ensemble in this rare opportunity to learn about music performance and create a new piece of music, to be performed live as part of the Acoustica series at Melbourne City Library. Ben Opie, Melissa Doecke and Phoebe Green will lead discussions on their experience of commissioning new works, arranging existing compositions and interpreting extant works.
As part of these workshops, Inventi Ensemble members will perform pieces that can demonstrate some of the many techniques they use to express themselves through music.
Participants will learn about pushing the boundaries of musical instruments and how to use these techniques in the process of creating a piece of music. Inventi Ensemble will guide you in how new works are created, ranging from improvisation to interpretation to graphic scores.
Musical knowledge and music reading skills are not required - just come along with your creative ideas and explore how they can be translated into music. All you need is your imagination and enthusiasm!
This event is presented by Inventi Ensemble and Acoustica as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: AURIN Urban Mapping Workshop
item.description:
Explore data about Melbourne's suburbs and Australia's cities in this Melbourne Knowledge Week workshop.
During this workshop you will extract information using the sophisticated tools contained within the Australian Urban Research Infrastructure Network (AURIN) portal, so you can mould this information into visualisable and sharable knowledge. Until now, much of this information has remained behind closed doors. AURIN enables access to this data for built environment professionals across all fields, letting users discover and mash-up data, information and knowledge.
Participants will undertake exercises in studying health data, visualising walkability of neighbourhoods and more. Knowledge of these issues is essential to understanding patterns of urban development, to form and model urban growth for a sustainable future.
This event is presented by the Australian Urban Research Infrastructure Network as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: A Melbourne Boston Knowledge Exchange
item.description:
You are invited to discover the reputation Melbourne and Boston share as world-leading knowledge cities.
Join leaders with a passion for knowledge for a special cocktail reception during Melbourne Knowledge Week, including the official announcement of the 2014 Hugh Rogers Fellows, a showcase of the 2013 Hugh Rogers Fellows and their experiences in both cities, and an opportunity to network and connect with other leaders passionate about Melbourne and Boston.
The showcase of 2013 Hugh Rogers Fellows MBSCA will feature the important contribution being made by past Hugh Rogers Fellows, with a panel discussion where 2013 recipients will share information about the research and projects undertaken in the past year in Boston. Find out how their fellowship experiences have enhanced the reputation of Melbourne and Boston as centres of knowledge excellence, as well as their own field of work internationally and locally within their institutions in Melbourne.
The showcase will include four inspiring female Melbourne knowledge leaders: Dr Lauren Ayton, Centre for Eye Research Australia (City of Melbourne Fellow, Healthcare & Medical Research); Ms Christine Healey, Heide Museum of Modern Art (Education); Dr Rebecca Lim, The Ritchie Centre, Monash Institute of Medical Research (Healthcare & Medical Research); and Ms Gemma Turvey, The New Palm Court Orchestra (The Arts and Culture).
Attendees will have the opportunity to pose questions to the 2013 Hugh Rogers Fellows and discover more about their work and experiences being a part of this Melbourne Boston knowledge exchange.
As part of Melbourne Knowledge Week, MBSCA will officially announce recipients of the 2014 Hugh Rogers Fellowships in the areas of healthcare, medical research and biotechnology, education, and the arts and culture.
This event is presented by the Melbourne Boston Sister Cities Association as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week.

item.title: Marysville Art Show
item.description:
The premier event on the regional arts calendar the Marysville Arts Show is on again over the Melbourne Cup Weekend with a grand opening night on October the 31st.
The theme of this years show is Great Art by Great Artists and the exhibition showcases local and regional Artists. The exhibition is being held in the Marysville Community Centre in Falls road Marysville and is open to all. Monies raised from the Art Show go to support local arts projects.
The opening night is shaping up as the not to be missed night of the year. Come along and meet the Artists, see and buy the wonderful works and be entertained as well. Special guest at the opening is bush poet and raconteur Jim Brown who will be reciting some of his poignant works themed around the ANZACs and Marysville after the fires. Music will be provided by talented local musicians on harp, fiddle, pipes and pans. The whole community and local businesses have come together to host this event.
Judging this year's event is renowned artist Max Wilkes. Max will judge the first prize, being the $1500 Murrindindi Shire Award, second the Gould memorial prize as well as Triangle Real Estate and the local business awards. Patrons and visitors will have their chance to judge the works in the People Choice Award.
The talented local VCE students have been given the opportunity to exhibit some of their works in the emerging artists section. Works from Artists on Acheron will also be on display. Another feature of this years show is the Children's section to be judged by Lenny the Leadbeater's possum. This event will be judged on the Saturday morning at the Children's exhibition space.

item.title: Children's Week at Cobram Library
item.description:
All children are encouraged to join the Cobram Library and receive a free book during Children's Week! The first fifty children to join the Cobram Library in Children's Week will receive a fabulous free book to encourage and develop a love for reading.
Children who are already members of the library and visit during Children's Week will be entered in a raffle to win book prizes.

item.title: McClelland Sculpture Survey & Award 2014
item.description:
Since its inception in 2003, the McClelland Sculpture Survey & Award has emerged as the most important biennial outdoor sculpture exhibition in Australia. The exhibition presents 35 works in an outdoor exhibition that highlights the diversity and invention of contemporary sculpture.
The 34 finalists will be eligible for the acquisitive McClelland Award of $100,000.00 for outdoor sculpture, the McClelland Achievement Prize (MAP) of $30,000 which also includes a solo exhibition at McClelland and the Frankston City People's Choice Award of $20,000.
The winner of the McClelland Award and the McClelland Achievement Prize will be announced on Sunday 23 November 2014.
Dr Liz Kreijin, Assistant Director Collection and Presentation, Kröller-Müller Museum, Netherlands will judge the McClelland Award 2014.
The Kröller-Müller Museum is internationally recognised as one of the world's premier Sculpture Parks, set on over 25 hectares, it displays over 170 objects including works by Marta Pan, Jean Dubuffet, Richard Serra, Atelier van Lieshout, Chris Booth and Jan Fabre.
The McClelland Sculpture Survey & Award was established in 2003 and quickly established itself as the most influential and prestigious exhibition of outdoor public sculpture in Australia. It brings together a wide range of sculptors from emerging, mid-career and established artists, working in wide range of styles and different media. It truly encapsulates the best of current sculpture practice. The 34 selected Survey sculptures will be displayed along a picturesque sculpture trail which winds its way through a variety of natural bush landscape and grasslands making it both an art and nature experience.
The McClelland Sculpture Survey & Award is proudly supported by The Balnaves Foundation and the Elisabeth Murdoch Sculpture Fund.

item.title: Yang Fudong: Filmscapes
item.description:
Filmscapes is Australia's largest-ever survey of China's pre-eminent moving-image artist, Yang Fudong, showing at the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI).
Chinese artist Yang Fudong has firmly established himself as one of the world's most extraordinary moving-image artists. His work's lyrical and dreamlike qualities, long and suspended sequences, spiraling narratives and multiple perspectives reflect the psychology of a new generation as it struggles to find its place in present-day China.
Stylistically rooted in Chinese painting, Yang Fudong's multi-channel film installations also reflect a fascination with international cinema, and in particular, film noir.
ACMI also presents a one-off screening of Yang's epic Seven Intellectuals in a Bamboo Forest (2003-2007), which is the first time that all five parts of this landmark film have been presented end-to-end in a cinema.
Yang Fudong is represented by ShanghART Gallery, Shanghai, and Marian Goodman Gallery, New York.
Yang Fudong: Filmscapes is presented as part of ACMI's special summer season China Up Close.

ns0:venue.name: Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI)

item.title: Community Health Expo
item.description:
This Community Health Expo has grown out of the vision of a few local residents who want to make sure their community feels supported after recent traumatic events including the grass fires. Everyone is invited. It is a free event and supper will be provided.
This is not a fire readiness expo but rather an opportunity for everyone who lives in the Sunbury, Riddles Creek, Darraweit Guim, Romsey, Kilmore, Wallan areas to gather, share stories and understand the services out there and how they work together to keep our families and property safe.
The event will be both an expo of service providers displaying and discussing what services they can offer us. There will also be a host of fantastic speakers show casing innovative local practices and achievements helping to make our community safer, stronger, more resilient and better prepared to manage any emergency situation.
Time: 5pm to 9pm

item.title: Longford Lions Christmas Parade and Market
item.description:
Longford Lions Christmas Parade and Market will take place on Saturday 6 December 2014, 8.00am to 1.00pm.
The Market will start at Brennan Park Sale at 8.00 am and the Street Parade will commence at 10.00 am at The St. Columbus Car Park continuing along Raymond Street finishing at Brennan Park, where Santa will be arriving. At 12.00 the Sale - Maffra Toy run will be arriving.

image.altText: Longford Lions Christmas Parade and Market
Longford Lions Christmas Parade and Market

item.title: Guest Cellar Door at Barwite Vineyard
item.description:
Guest Cellar Door at Barwite Vineyard is an opportunity to sample and buy boutique wines of distinction from six local labels in a magnificent vineyard setting with live music.
Special prices just for you and your Christmas table. Luncheon platters will also be available prepared by Ben Davies from the Culinarian. Come along and enjoy the day and bring your friends Bookings for lunch are recommended.

image.altText: Guest Cellar Door at Barwite Vineyard
Guest Cellar Door at Barwite Vineyard

item.title: Talbot Farmers Market
item.description:
On the third Sunday every month the Talbot Farmers' Market comes alive as thousands of visitors enjoy the vibrant village atmosphere.
Explore an evolving display of over 80 regional produce stalls, including seasonal fruit and organic vegetables, local artisan cheese, fresh bread, local wine, gourmet oils, delicious delicacies and more. In true country farmers' market style you will also find pigs, goats and chooks, stockfeed, cut flowers, plants and seedlings.
Sample fabulous food and wine, enjoy a coffee and a tasty bite to eat while listening to local artists playing live music in the street.
Pick up a ticket for your chance to win the 'Barrow Raffle' overflowing with wonderful produce kindly donated by our stall holders.
Remember to bring your shopping bags or grab a gorgeous calico bag from the information marquee.
Browse for unexpected treasures at the adjacent Town Hall Market.
Talbot is just 40 minutes north of Ballarat or 90 minutes from Melbourne's Westgate Bridge.

item.title: Sports Boat and PWC Expo
item.description:
Just a two hour drive from Melbourne, Bonnie Doon, on the banks of Lake Eildon, is the new home of the Sports Boat and PWC Expo for 2014.
The two day event is a free event, to be held in conjunction with the Lake Eildon Festival. With boat displays both off, and on the water, this is your chance to really check out Australia's best sports boats from the ground up and then head out on the lake to see what they are like floating.
There will be professional wakeboard and waterski demos throughout the weekend world-champion coaching opportunities, boat license testing and plenty of entertainment for both young and old. The Bonnie Doon Hotel will be hosting the event, making meals, snacks, and refreshments, readily available to get your hands on throughout the weekend.
Keep an eye on their Facebook page for the latest.

item.title: Smart Cities with Digital Skins: What will this mean for you?
item.description:
The internet of things and smart technology is already impacting the way everyone understands and uses cities.
Hear how sensors are changing everyone's lives and how everyone uses and manages metadata.
Will 'smart cities' deliver greater economic and public good? What about liveability and privacy?
Held during Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014 and MC'd by ABC Radio National's Antony Funnell, this event features Deakin University's Chief Digital Officer, William Confalonieri among other leading industry experts.

item.title: British Heraldry of the Great War
item.description:
This lecture, largely illustrated with images from the records of the College of Arms, will discuss the representation of the Great War in the armorial bearings granted to various military and naval commanders, armament manufacturers and others. The arms will be set in the context of older English heraldic traditions. The heraldic consequences of George V's desire to sever his family's ties with Germany will also be discussed.
The lecture will be presented by David Vines White and be held in the Auditorium, Education Centre at the Shrine of Remembrance
The event is free but gold coin donation welcome.

image.altText: British Heraldry of the Great War
British Heraldry of the Great War

item.title: Children's week- Community Children Wyndhamvale
item.description:
Community Children Wyndham will be celebrating Children's week, with activities running all throughout the week.
Activities included over the week are: cooking sessions, reading sessions- the children are invited to bring in a special book from home to share with the class, music sessions with a visit from Music Makers, visit from Yoga bugs who will engage with the kinder children in a yoga session, with the three and four year olds will take daily walks through the local community and enjoy a play in the local playgrounds.
Grandparents day also falls on the 26th of October so celebrations will be extending to Monday the 27th to hold a grandparents afternoon tea service to express our respect and gratitude to extended family members in our community.

item.title: Gippsland Woodcraft Group Makers Market and Craft Day
item.description:
Gippsland Woodcraft Group will host a Makers Market and Craft Day.
Featuring needlework, jams and preserves, cakes, woodcraft demos, timber slabbing, quilting, lace making, wool spinning, chainsaw carver and a car display.
BBQ and Drinks will be available on the day.
Stalls available in the Hall or Outside. $10 a site.
Event runs from 8am to 2pm.

image.altText: Gippsland Woodcraft Group Makers Market and Craft Day

item.title: Licola Wilderness Village Family Open Day
item.description:
The Licola Wilderness Village Family Open Day is on again.
With adventure activities such as the 150 metre Flying Fox, canoeing, 18 metre giant swing, climbing, archery, high ropes course, leap of faith from $2.50 a go.
With many free activities from bouncy castle, face painting, mini golf, trampolines, bouldering, indoor sports, bocce and much, much more why go anywhere else.
Kids - bring your parents for a challenging fun filled action packed day out.
Day visitors welcome or accommodation available.
Event will run from 10am to 4pm with free entry.

item.title: Taraleigh Steiner Preschool & Playgroup St. Nicholas Day Fair
item.description:
The Taraleigh Steiner Preschool & Playgroup St. Nicholas Day Fair is a community run annual event providing a great family day out.
The fair is held in the beautiful grounds of Taraleigh, there will be the usual community favourites such as a cake stall selling delicious treats, a raffle for a chance to win some great prizes, and a silent auction offering the chance to grab a bargain.
The craft market provides a treasure trove of gifts just in time for Christmas or to treat yourself with. Most of the stalls sell goods which are handmade, sustainably sourced and/or eco-friendly, in line with kinder's philosophy of Steiner Education. The Taraleigh Craft Group stall will have a range of beautiful handmade felt toys and crowns, ribbon wands and Advent Sticks all of which are lovingly created by parents of the Taraleigh community. The Playgroup parents will be running a second-hand book stall with bargains galore.
Entertainment includes live acoustic music, bongo drum workshop and traditional choir. There will be a storytelling session followed by a special visit by St. Nicholas for the kids, accompanied by a choir.
Kids activities include a sandpit treasure hunt, story time, candle rolling, and bags to tie dye. For the kids and adults we have a traditional Coconut Shy for everyone to try their luck at, how many coconuts will you be able to knock down?
There will be sausages in bread to snack on, dahl and rice for hungry tummies, and homemade lemonade cordial and Chai.

item.title: Framed Movements
item.description:
Presented by Melbourne Festival and Australian Centre for Contemporary Art, Framed Movements investigates the potential that lies at the shifting boundaries between dance and art.
Exploring the many ways a movement based approach to the occupation of time and space is practised not only in dance but increasingly in the realm of contemporary art, the exhibition brings together a series of Australian and international artists who use a choreographic approach in their work.
A series of performances will accompany the exhibition, drawing attention to the potential of the body in space and its ability to draw you into a physical conversation with the world around you.
Exhibiting artists: Gwenneth Boelens, Ann Carlson & Mary Ellen Strom, Lane Cormick, Brian Fuata, Alicia Frankovich, Agatha Gothe-Snape, Nathan Gray, Helen Grogan, Maria Hassabi, Joachim Koester, Paulina Olowska, Jess Olivieri, Hayley Forward & Parachutes for Ladies, Emily Roysdon, Sandra Selig and Lee Serle.

image.altText: Maria Hassabi, Intermission 2013. Courtesy the artist.
Maria Hassabi, Intermission 2013. Courtesy the artist.

item.title: Avenel Primary School Fete and Clearing Sale
item.description:
Held at the Avenel Primary School grounds with lots of fun and action for everyone, grab a bargain from the huge auction which takes place on the oval or from one of many market stalls scattered around the grounds.
Heaps of activities to keep the kids entertained including jumping castle and giant slide.
Great food available from the barbecue or cafe.
Lots of great prizes to be won in the raffle, so come along and join us for a great day out.
Time: 10am to 2pm.

item.title: A Taste of French Terroirs
item.description:
The French-Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Sopexa take great pleasure in inviting you to the Wine Trade Tasting; A Taste of French Terroirs.
This trade-only event will give you the opportunity to sample a fine selection of wines from various French regions and terroirs, and meet with the representatives of the participating wineries.
If you are a professional and you wish to attend this trade tasting: RSVP essential by Friday 21 November 2014 to Bertrand Cauvin the Business Development & Trade Coordinator at French-Australian or RSVP online.
item.ns0:organiser: French Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry

item.title: Imhoff: a life of grain & pixels
item.description:
An exhibition at the Art Gallery of Ballarat highlights the work of Robert Imhoff, an Australian photographer and filmmaker who not only built up a very successful career as a commercial photographer but also established a reputation as one of Australia's leading portrait photographers.
Imhoff's love affair with photography began in the same way as it did for many young photographers: with a Kodak Box Brownie, while his professional career started after studying photography at RMIT in the late 1960s.
A career break came when he was invited to do a four-page spread featuring Wittner Shoes for insertion in the March 1971 edition of Vogue Australia. The images featured shoes on model's feet that were draped around a naked female body. Although the shot featuring Gaye Baker doesn't show much flesh by today's standards, the use of the naked female form was seen as ground-breaking for Vogue Australia.
Imhoff tended to work for the upper end of the consumer market, undertaking commissions for perfume, cars, fashion and airlines.
This retrospective exhibition, Imhoff: A life of grains and pixels, documents his career as a professional photographer and filmmaker, including portraits of celebrities and the not so well known, photography for specialist food magazines that began to emerge in the 1970s, and assignments for a number of multinational companies.

image.altText: Imhoff: a life of grain & pixels

item.title: Dominique Portet: Marche Francais en Yarra Valley
item.description:
A dash of French flair will come to Victoria's Yarra Valley on November 30 when renowned winery Dominique Portet stage their very own Marche Francais.
Back for its second year, the Portet's open-air French Market will celebrate all things en français in the sprawling surrounds of the family's Yarra Valley winery. The Portet family belong to ten generations of wine-makers, and the French Market will be infused with a pedigree in joi de vivre that stretches all the way back to 18th Century France.
Market revelers can indulge in a specially curated collection of wares, tastes and treats from the Yarra Valley and beyond against the backdrop of the Portet's vineyards and cellar door. Enjoy hosted wine tastings and winery tours, sample the delicacies on offer including crepes, baguettes and brulees; handcrafted truffles, artisan breads, pastries, macarons, coffee and micro brews from neighbouring breweries - and oooh-la-la over the spécialités françaises for the home and garden.
Graze on baguettes, try your hand at petanque, sip on the Portet's famous Sparkling Rosé or simply take in the fresh air amongst the vines as a rolling line up of live music transports you to Provence.

image.altText: Dominique Portet: Marche Francais en Yarra Valley
Dominique Portet: Marche Francais en Yarra Valley

item.title: Substation Farmers' Market
item.description:
The Victorian Farmers Market Association accredited Substation Farmers' Market in Newport runs on the first and third Sundays of each month, offering a fantastic variety of fresh Victorian produce and a direct connection to local food producers.
The market features around 35 stallholders, offering a wide array of food from eggs, meat, fruit and vegetables to fresh pasta, cheese, wine, nuts and herbs, as well as plenty of things to eat and drink at the market.

item.title: Gravity
item.description:
Join Melbourne band Gravity as they cover many of the latest and greatest tracks of all time at the Howlong Country Golf Club!
It's a great way to kick off the Melbourne Cup week!

item.title: The Alcove Art Shop Christmas A'Fair Exhibition
item.description:
The annual Alcove Art Shop Christmas A'fair will bring together a wonderful array of beautifully hand-crafted items by their artisans. The artists create unique works including ceramics, jewellery, paintings, woodwork, cards and textiles, just to name a few.
They invite you to join them during this exhibition and delight in the creations. You may even find something special to take home, for yourself or your loved ones.

item.title: Sandringham Village Festival
item.description:
The Sandringham Village Festival has been running for over five years and each year gets bigger and better.
The streets in the Village area, bounded by Station, Melrose and Waltham Streets, are closed for the day. Sandringham traders will be open and there will be market stalls, food, and local community groups.
For the children there are four amusements including a jumping castle, swing chairs, giant slide and animal farm, a magician and an appearance by the star of children's literature, Andy Griffiths, who will be on the Melrose Street stage.
A great programme of live music is scheduled for our two stages from local performers as well as celtic folk band, Saoirse, Kings of Leisure, and popular cover band, Two Dogs.
St Kilda Football star Lenny Hayes will be signing his memoir, "Lenny: My Story" in Melrose Street.
For more information, please see website.

item.title: Longbeach Storybook Yarn Art Trail 2014
item.description:
The Longbeach Storybook Yarn Art Trail 2014 is a celebration of Yarn Art & Craft for Senior's Month and Children's Week. This event will run from 6 October to 31st October.
Stop 1: Longbeach Place, 15 Chelsea Road, Chelsea Stop 2: Chelsea Primary School, 34 - 44 Argyle Avenue, Chelsea Stop 3: 'Hungry Caterpillar' Food Trail - Argyle Avenue, Chelsea Stop 4: Chelsea Heights Community Centre, 160 Thames Promenade, Chelsea Heights Stop 5: Chelsea Heights Primary School, 194 Thames Promenade, Chelsea Heights Stop 6: Bonbeach Primary School, 29 - 63 Breeze Street, Bonbeach Stop 7: St. Francis Xavier Primary School, 8 Park Street, Frankston

item.title: The Philosophy Club presents Possible Futures
item.description:
Kids, get your thinking caps on and join The Library at the Dock as they explore big questions about the future!
The Philosophy Club brings you workshops about the future, for kids who always ask 'why?' and never settle for 'just because'. These small-group 'thinking' workshops will get kids pondering big questions that face humanity in the 21st century and beyond.
These workshops are led by professional facilitators of The Philosophy Club, experienced in helping children think collaboratively, engage with big questions and explore stimulating ideas.
There are two age-specific workshops:
- To Boldly Go Where No Child Has Gone Before for children ages 8 to 9 years: Space travel, interplanetary colonisation and extra-terrestrial intelligence are our springboards for exploring ethics in the far distant future. Experience an astronaut's launch into space with a dramatic simulation of lift-off, followed by a philosophical enquiry into why we might want to explore space. Explore real-life space capsules designed to reach out to extra-terrestrial civilisations, and even design and launch a space capsule of your own!
- When Things Start to Think for children ages 10 to 12 years: What does it mean to have a mind? Who or what has a mind? Does Wall-E think? What about a smartphone? A thermostat? Videos from cutting-edge robotics laboratories provide stimuli for an enquiry about artificial intelligence. How can we know whether a machine is really thinking or feeling? How can we know whether the person sitting beside us is really thinking or feeling?
These workshops are free, but bookings are essential. Please follow the link to our booking page to secure your child's place.
This event is part of Melbourne Knowledge Week.

item.title: St Arnaud Family Fun Day
item.description:
Come along to the St Arnaud Family Fun Day, what will be a fantastic family fun day.
There will be face painting, temporary tattoos, jumping castle, ferret racing, jellybean count, gigantic bubbles, minute-to-win-it games, craft stand for kids, sausage sizzle and much, much more!

item.title: Thriller Dance Australian Record
item.description:
They're out to get you, there's demons closing in on every side, they will possess you. Get along to Rosedale this Halloween and get your zombie on! Take part in the Australian record attempt for Michael Jackson's Thriller dance.
Rosedale's amazing Haunted House will open from Dusk, and there will be heaps of kids entertainment and food from 5pm.

item.title: GBEN Small Business Solutions Forum
item.description:
A one stop shop for resources, grants, assistance, programs and information for start up businesses and SMEs.
Hear from a small business owner, learn what government and other services are available to help you start and grow your business, ask questions, network, and get access to over 10 agencies in one place.
Participants include AusIndustry, ASIC, BEC, CAV, ICN, INNOVIC, IP Australia, Office of the Small Bus. Commisioner, SBV, Workcover and the FairWork Ombudsman.
Be informed! Be Inspired!

item.title: Alfa Romeo Club Spettacolo Concorso and Show and Shine
item.description:
The Alfa Romeo Owners Club (Vic Div) is holding its annual Spettacolo Concorso and Show 'n' Shine at a well known location at Wesley College, St Kilda Road campus.
On Sunday, Spettacolo is expected to have up to 300 Alfa Romeos on the field. This year's theme will be 60 years of the Giulietta sponsored by Essendon Alfa Romeo in addition to a 'Zagato Showcase' sponsored by Tiamo Restaurant and 10 years of the 932 GT sponsored by Berwick and Pakenham Alfa Romeo. The club warmly invites all Alfa Romeo owners to join us for the day.

item.title: Children's Week at Tiny Treasures Early Learning Centre
item.description:
Tiny Treasures Early Learning Centre is celebrating Children's Week.
The centre has placed a special program for the children at Tiny Treasures and the children within the local community.
Monday, 20th October 2014 - Donate or borrow a book program (Kindly donate children's book and you can borrow up to three children's books for one week to read to your little ones, 10am to 4pm)
Tuesday, 21st October 2014 - Gardening Day - (Please join in and help the children plant trees, veggies, fruits or herbs on this day, 1pm to 4pm)
Wednesday, 22nd October 2014 - Get Kids Active Day (A fitness program for all age groups sessions are from 10:00am to 10:45am and 3pm to 3:45pm)
Thursday, 23rd October 2014 - The Things We Love Day (Magazine clipping workshop for children two years and older and Messy play for babies & toddlers - only available for children enrolled at Tiny Treasures)
Friday, 24th October 2014 - Special Friends Day (Workshops and Afternoon tea for everyone! from 2:30pm to 4pm)

item.title: Benalla Festival
item.description:
As Spring and the warmer weather creep in, the Benalla community look forward to and welcome the Benalla Festival of fun and creativity.
The Benalla Festival has grown and evolved over the years to become an annual highlight on the city's events calendar and something people look forward to being a part of.
It provides an opportunity to connect with each other and appreciate the beautiful surrounds and spirit of country living.
The Benalla Festival Advisory Committee invites you to take the journey to celebrate this year's Benalla Festival theme Regional Harvest, celebrating the local producers.
The Benalla Festival Advisory Committee would like to thank its major partners, sponsors and Friends of the Festival. Their support enables the events to be free or low cost. As well as extending a big thank you to the community volunteers and the members of the Benalla Festival Advisory Committee, and school groups who have worked so hard to deliver the Festival.

item.title: Linden Postcard Show
item.description: The Linden Postcard Show is a unique open entry competition that sees hundreds of small format contemporary artworks adorn the gallery walls at Linden. With all artwork for sale, it's the ideal exhibition to discover an affordable treasure or the perfect gift.

item.title: Moonee Ponds Primary School Spring Fete 2014
item.description:
Moonee Ponds Primary School's Spring Fete is on this October. Fun for the whole family is guaranteed with live music and entertainment, amusement rides, homemade cakes and preserves, plants, crafts, toys and books for sale, tattoos, face painting, silent auctions, bar and fantastic food stalls, side show alley and so much more.
The event will run from 10am to 4pm. Please see the website for more information.

item.title: Storytelling through Plasticine Illustration
item.description:
Join the Creswick Library to create your story and your own plasticine characters.
Local Artist and Illustrator Sam Harmer will provide the tools and the skills your imagination does the rest.
Three sessions will be available for ages prep - 2, grades 3-4 and 5-6.
Children must book as space is limited.

item.title: Children's Week across Hindmarsh Shire Council
item.description:
Children's week is celebrated annually and this year Hindmarsh Shire Council is proud to present Wiggi the Clown! Wiggi is a travelling performer based in St Kilda, Victoria.
Wiggi will perform in both Nhill and Jeparit for all children aged between 0-12.
Wiggi's performance in Jeparit will be from 9am-10am at the Jeparit Primary School.
Nhills performance will be held during playgroup on Friday October 24th 2014 from 1030am at the Nhill Kindergarten. Children are invited to dress up in a circus theme.
Hindmarsh Shire Council will also be hosting a colouring in competition throughout the Shire's four towns. One winner will be announced from each town, with exciting prizes to be won!

image.altText: Children's Week across Hindmarsh Shire Council
Children's Week across Hindmarsh Shire Council

item.title: Snapperfest
item.description:
Celebrate the start of the fishing season in Port Albert over the Melbourne Cup Weekend as the town comes alive with music, food and free family entertainment for Snapperfest celebrations.
The activities start with a scary movie night on Friday at the Port Albert Hall. The first showing will commence at 5pm with movies getting scarier as the night goes on until its completion at midnight.
On Saturday, the hall will be transformed to host an underage disco aimed at the young and the young at heart. Everybody is welcome to come along to this Halloween themed event. Music will once again be provided by Mikes Mobile Music Mix.
Sunday is the Snapperfest Day. There will be a morning market at the Port Albert Hall, with free family entertainment in nearby Rutter Park food stall, hay bale maze, live music and plenty of room for everyone.
Local restaurants and cafes will be focusing on a seafood theme so everybody has a chance to enjoy some fresh local produce.

item.title: Visible Music Sessions
item.description:
Multicultural Arts Victoria has joined force with the Melbourne Festival for the fourth year in a row presenting Igniting Imagination - a program that appoints culturally diverse Festival Ambassadors who are leaders in their artistic practice and communities, and for 2014, a series of free live music events featuring some of Melbourne's top emerging musicians who have been in Multicultural Arts Victoria's Visible Music Mentoring Program.
Multicultural Arts Victoria has programmed Visible Music Sessions in the Melbourne Festival every Sunday, free at the Foxtel Festival Hub that will feature some of the brightest stars from Multicultural Arts Victoria's Visible Music Mentoring Program.
Visible has kick-started the careers of emerging musicians from refugee, Indigenous and emerging backgrounds teaming them with leading musicians in this country, so these sessions will feature some of the most unusual and innovative creations the music industry has seen to date.
See website for full program details.
item.ns0:organiser: Multicultural Arts Victoria and The Melbourne Festival

item.title: Annual Spring Plant Sale at Tindale Garden
item.description:
Come to Friends of George Tindale Memorial Garden spring plant sale located in the fabulous Dandenong Ranges!
Plants propagated from our collection will include hydrangeas, bulbs, cyclamen, cliveas, hellebores and many shade loving perennials. Some sun loving plants also on sale.
All monies raised will be used to assist with ongoing improvements to the garden.
Admission is free and parking is just outside the entry gates.
Time: 10am to 4pm

item.title: Strawberry Affair: A Match Made In Heaven!
item.description:
The Yarra Valley's new strawberry season will get off to a delicious start by celebrating one of the most loved culinary combinations - strawberries and chocolate at the Yarra Valley Chocolaterie & Ice Creamery.
Strawberry Affair will see the European Chocolatiers transform the bounty of new season strawberries into a showcase of limited edition, decadent couverture chocolate and strawberry combinations.
Indulge your desire for this match made in heaven with chocolate dipped strawberries in your choice of white, milk or dark couverture, handcrafted strawberry truffles; a changing array of fresh cakes, tarts, torts and pastries inspired by new season strawberries and chocolate; giant scoops of their house made strawberry ice cream, freshly baked scones with the best strawberry jam, strawberry sundaes or strawberry milkshakes.
Tempted? Make a date to visit them for a Strawberry Affair.

item.title: Childrens Week - Renew, Reuse, Recyclye- making little green steps
item.description:
Children's Week is a national program recognising the talents, skills, achievements and rights of young people. It is based on the articles expressed in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, highlighting play, wellbeing and protection.
This year's theme is Renew Reuse Recycle, making little green steps to support children's future.
The family friendly event will include activities that support renewing everyday items, educational games on what and how to recycle and interactive workshops on how to reuse items from around the home.
The Surf Coast Shire is working collaboratively with five townships in celebrating Children's week with the support of the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development.
Monday 20 October at Lorne Bike park between Otway street and Cypress avenue from 2-4pm Tuesday 21 October at Torquay, Elephant Walk 10-1pm Wednesday 22 October at Moriac, Newling Reserve 10.30-12.30 Thursday 23 October Winchelsea, Uniting Church hall 1pm-3pm Friday 24th October Deans Marsh Playground 11pm-1pm

item.title: Dementia: Understanding to Action - Melbourne
item.description:
Alzheimer's Australia Vic is on the road with Dementia: Understanding to Action, an information-packed community event covering three sessions on:
An understanding of dementia: learn what dementia is, its main causes, key signs and symptoms, the relationship between brain and behaviour and identify main risk factors.
Your brain matters: research shows that living a brain healthy life, a person's risk of developing dementia may be reduced. Learn the five simple steps to maximise your brain health.
From diagnosis to support: what you can do if concerned that someone you know has signs of dementia, how to seek an assessment and what support is available in your area. Counsellors will be on-site to answer questions.
Proudly sponsored by Exxon Mobil.
Timings: 10:00am - 10:15am Registration and refreshment, 10:15am - 11:15am An Understanding of Dementia: 11:15am - 11:35am Morning tea 11:35am - 12:25pm Your Brain Matters 12:25pm - 13:15pm From diagnosis to support
For more information please visit the website.

item.title: Bass Coast Children's Expo
item.description:
The Bass Coast Children's Expo is an annual event showcasing fun activities and services for families and children.
The 2014 expo, to be held at the State Coal Mine promises to be lots of fun with old fashioned games, buskers, entertainment, café, children's services information, face painting, children's activities, jumping castle, Frisbee golf, popcorn, and much more!
The expo will run from 10.00am through to 1.00pm.
Raffle tickets, fruit and water will be provided.
There is plenty of free parking available at the State Coal Mine.

item.title: Freshwater Creek Steiner School Spring Fair & Open Day
item.description:
The Spring Fair is the highlight of the year at the Freshwater Creek Steiner School, just half an hour from Geelong in a bush setting.
It is a celebration for school families who invite neighbours and visitors to join them and take in the atmosphere of their beautiful school.
Parents and children bake cakes to enjoy at Chai Cafe, along with homemade savoury food and the good old fashioned sausage sizzle - with sausages made from biodynamically raised meat. Homemade lemonade, jams and preserves will be available for purchase, along with organically grown produce.
The school's craft co-op stall offers goods made by hand with natural materials, displaying the talent of the school community. This stall will also sell second-hand Steiner toys. A vibrant marketplace will showcase quality, handmade, natural and sustainable goods.
Acoustic music from children, local musicians and buskers will provide a melodious backdrop as visitors browse the stalls, or sit to rest and refresh themselves.
In the free games area, children will be able to dig for gnomes' gold, fish for brightly coloured fish, and play a range of games to suit all ages.
Education and excitement go hand in hand: a display of young native animals; the Viking tents of the Dubh-Linn branch of The New Varangian Guard (aka The Vikings in Geelong); building a birdhouse with the Geelong East Men's Shed; and the Freshwater Creek CFA and their truck.
The fair is on Saturday, 25 October, and starts at 10am.

item.title: Southgate Cinema
item.description:
A new film program heralds the on-set of spring from September to November at Southgate Cinema, Melbourne's only silent cinema. A new season of the long-running and free Tuesday movie nights will be programmed until May 2015.
Already an attractive anomaly as a free deckchair cinema, Southgate Cinema now offers a unique 'Blue Class' experience with a movie menu delivered to your deckchair from next-door eatery Bluetrain, recently refurbished with a critically acclaimed new design.
Southgate cinephiles can devour gourmet pizzas and graze on an eclectic variety of tasting platters with selections including a Bollywood platter, soft shell taco platter and Chinese five spice chicken ribs as they sit back and watch films like The Book Thief, Tracks and The Hunger Games 2: Catching Fire, with headphones and audio kits.
In November, Southgate Cinema films celebrate the theme of freedom with Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom, 12 Years a Slave and Inside Llewlyn Davis programed along with acclaimed but selectively screened Australian film Around the Block, about an Aboriginal boy in Redfern torn between his unexpected love of acting and the disintegration of his family.
Celebrated by audiences and critics alike, Southgate Cinema is listed on Time Out Melbourne's Bucket List and as a Herald Sun Hidden Gem.
The full September-November Southgate Cinema program and Blue Class menu can be viewed online.
Surrounding the cinema is Southgate's diverse range of restaurants and bars, including newly opened Italian restaurant and wine bar ARTUSI, Bavarian bier hall Hophaus and Inuit and native North American inspired restaurant Amarok. A range of boutique retailers including vintage and fair trade fashion, designer homewares, art deco jewellery and antique art can also be found within the precinct.
This is a free event but bookings are required.

item.title: Finding Families at the State Library of Victoria
item.description:
Enter the intriguing world of genealogy and learn how to start building a family tree in this free introductory workshop for beginners at the State Library of Victoria.
Librarians from the Family History team will introduce the key principles of family history research. Learn how to access and use a range of resources, and take on a tour of the Library's Family History collection.

item.title: Wallan Relay for Life
item.description:
This unique event has been created to recognise and celebrate those who have overcome cancer or are undergoing treatment, as well as the people who care for them. It provides an opportunity to celebrate the memory of loved ones lost to cancer.
The event itself is organised by a dedicated team of community volunteers and encourages teams of 10-15 people to get together, fundraise and then participate in a relay-style walk or run, challenging them to stay on the track overnight!
You can stay for the whole event and camp out, enjoy a heap of fun activities and attend moving ceremonies which make the event so very special.
The town of Wallan is hosting on Saturday November 22nd commencing at 4pm and ending at 10am on Sunday 23rd of November on the second oval at Greenhills Reserve, Wallan.
If you would like to participate please register now!
We are always looking for volunteers and sponsors as well in any way, shape or form!

item.title: Remembering Black Saturday five years on
item.description:
The bushfires that ravaged Victoria on 7 February 2009 claimed the lives of 173 people and destroyed more than 2000 homes.
Five years on, Melbourne curator Liza Dale-Hallett and historian Robert Kenny reflect on Black Saturday and how the devastating event continues to shape their personal and professional lives at the State Library of Victoria.
Robert Kenny lost his home on that tragic day. When writing about his experiences in his 2013 book, Gardens of fire: an investigative memoir (UWAP), he wove his own story into a broader history of the relationship between settler Australians and fire.
Working closely with communities in the wake of the Black Saturday bushfires, Liza Dale-Hallett has led the development of the Victorian Bushfires Collection at Museum Victoria.
In this discussion, Liza and Robert consider the role of history and memory in the way we make sense of such traumatic events, and the role historians are playing in the recovery phase.

item.title: Halina's Garden
item.description:
Wallan Home Harvest presents Halina's Garden in Hidden Valley plus soil testing.
Wallan Home Harvest are members of the local community with an interest in growing and/or rearing our own produce. The group has a long term vision of a sustainable future by starting in our very own back yards, hoping to encourage many others to also do so along the way.
The group have regular monthly events and get together's aimed at sharing ideas, information and resources. New members with or without experience, families, individuals, the young and old are all most welcome!
Time: 9.30am - 11.30am
Morning tea provided

item.title: Coming Home: a social history exhibition
item.description:
Coming Home is a social history exhibition exploring the history of Bundoora Homestead as a Repatriation Mental Hospital for returned servicemen from 1920 until 1993. This free exhibition runs from 3 October to 7 December 2014.
Coming Home tells a story of state and national significance, and reveals elements of a little known chapter in the care and management of veterans suffering from mental disorders as a result of their war service.
Historical photographs from the National Archives of Australia, Australian War Memorial, Red Cross and City of Darebin Art and History Collection will be on display. Also included are artefacts, artworks and personal stories from a wide variety of private and public collections.

image.altText: 04_Dr John Cade at his Desk_Royal Park Mental Hospital_1970
04_Dr John Cade at his Desk_Royal Park Mental Hospital_1970

item.title: Oral history in the digital age
item.description:
Life stories surround everyone in this digital age. But what are the challenges and opportunities in creating, interpreting and producing digital oral histories today?
In this Making Public Histories seminar, US historian Professor Michael Frisch, one of the most influential contributors to international developments in oral and public history, explores this timely topic in depth.
In the 1970s, Professor Frisch led new interpretations of memory and history. In the 1980s, he coined the notion of 'shared authority' to illuminate the oral history relationship. Since the 1990s, he has worked at the cutting edge of digital technologies for creating, sharing and interpreting recorded interviews.
In this public lecture, Professor Frisch will use a social history of 20th-century Australian lives and memories, the Australian Generations Oral History Project, as one example to explore the transformation of oral history in our digital age.

item.title: Clyde Park 2015 Golden Plains Arts Trail
item.description:
The Clyde Park 2015 Golden Plains Arts Trail is a weekend adventure showcasing the work of artists of the Golden Plains region.
Visit usually private studios and other creative spaces to meet the artists and see exhibitions, demonstrations and workshops while exploring the towns, back lanes and diverse landscape of the Golden Plains. Check out performances and regional wine and food along the Trail.
The Golden Plains is close to Melbourne, Geelong and Ballarat.

item.title: Nomad - Float
item.description:
Nomad is a collaboration by Michele Donegan and Ara Dolatian, who install coloured woollen webs in galleries and public spaces. The work responds to the particular site, considering architecture and purpose, and the web reinvents each site by creating a sense of other-worldliness, transforming the nature of the space.
The work forms a 'shelter' that is reminiscent of nomads stopping and establishing a safe place for a period of time. The web is accessible to a wide public audience to explore, enjoy and be immersed in - and maybe even involved in during the installation period.
All welcome to come and view or participate in Nomad's installation process from 23rd September.

item.title: Halloween Spooky Storytime at East Melbourne Library
item.description:
It's time for fearless families to bring their little ghouls and boos to celebrate Spooky Storytime!
Celebrate with jokes, stories, music and party games. Wear your best costume and have a scream during storytime. There will be face painting, dress-ups and loads of scary activities to do. Plus special guest Wizard Silvernose.
Cautionary note, there will be nuts and colourants in food items. Suits ages three to six years.

item.title: Children of the Night at East Melbourne Library
item.description:
Come and celebrate Spook Night at East Melbourne Library, with devilish host Mr Lou Cyfer.
Show your ticket to the Ferry Man and bring out your inner demon with face painting. Win prizes for best joke, costume and story, and feast away the evening.
For your trick and treat, prepare your dance moves to Monster Mash, Ghost Busters or Time Warp, and get ready to hit the dance floor.
Please note that nuts and colourants will be in food items served.
This event suits children aged seven and over and their keepers.

item.title: Angliss Family Fun Day -Childrens Week
item.description:
Angliss Children's Centre in Footscray is turning 25 years old and celebrating Children's week 2014 with a Family Fun Day and Open Day full of fun activities and interactive workshops for pre-school children and their families.
Learn drumming, circus tricks, twirl hoola-hoops, decorate cup-cakes, make rice paper rolls, paint plant pots and more.
Held at Angliss Children's Centre the Family Fun Day is accessible by public transport or car and will be open between 10 am and 3 pm.
Children's activities and workshops are free.

item.title: Inverloch parkrun
item.description:
Inverloch parkrun is a free weekly timed five kilometre event for runners and walkers of all ages and abilities, which takes place every Saturday at 8 am, with a pre-run briefing at 7:45 am.
If you haven't been to a parkrun before, register online and print off your unique barcode to bring along with you to each parkrun event you attend. With your barcode in hand you will be able to record your time and see your results posted on their website.

item.title: Children's Week - Biodiversity of the Western Volcanic Plains
item.description: During Children's Week, Ecolinc will be featuring the Biodiversity of the Western Volcanic Plains. Students attending Ecolinc during Children's Week will be exploring the plants and animals of the Western Volcanic Plains using Ecolinc's new Flora and Fauna Field Guide app and a range of online outreach programs including Quadrats Online, Grassland Food Webs, Managing Grassland Ecosystems, Talk with the Experts, Virtual Tour to Mt Rothwell and an Interactive Quiz.

ns0:venue.name: Ecolinc Science and Technology Innovations Centre

image.altText: Children's Week - Biodiversity of the Western Volcanic Plains
Children's Week - Biodiversity of the Western Volcanic Plains

item.title: Children's Week at the Royal Children's Hospital
item.description:
The Royal Children's Hospital Education Institute will present daily art activities for children throughout Children's Week from 11am to 1pm.
Victorian Opera will perform Hansel and Gretel in German on Tuesday 21 October at 11.30am in the Ella Latham Auditorium. Please contact operator to register your interest in attending this performance.

image.altText: Children's Week at the Royal Children's Hospital
Children's Week at the Royal Children's Hospital

item.title: Kingston Toy Library Children's Week Family Fun Day
item.description:
Kingston Toy Library Children's Week Family Fun Day is a free community fun day for all families across the municipality to celebrate children, families and having fun.
The event will feature an animal farm, sporting activities, face-painting, and many of the Toy Library toys, a jumping castle, baby-play activities, play dough and sand activities and much more. With food and drink available this will be a great family day out.
Held at the Peter Scullin Reserve also known as the Pirate Ship playground from 9.30 to 2pm, there is plenty of parking and only a five min walk with pram from the Mordialloc train station.

item.title: Petanque Triples Tournament
item.description:
Held in High street Avoca over the weekend, the Pyrenees Petanque Triples Tournament is one of Central Victoria's premium petanque competitions.
Fully sanctioned by the Petanque Federation of Australia, the event is open to all licensed members of PFA affiliated clubs.
If you have never played Petanque but are curious about this International game, come along and check out the action. You will have the opportunity to meet players from local and interstate clubs over the lunch break and the chance to arrange a 'try out' on a club day if you would like to.
The Pyrenees Petanque Club promotes Petanque as a family friendly, low impact sport open to players of all ages and abilities. Club members enjoy sharing the tactics, strategies and techniques of the game and encourage newcomers to improve their skills and enjoy the benefits of club membership.

item.title: Mitchell Shire Pet Expo
item.description:
On Saturday 15th November Mitchell Shire Council will be holding its annual Pet Expo from 10am - 3pm.
The Pet Expo aims to promote Responsible Pet Ownership to residents of Mitchell Shire.
A variety of displays, demonstrations and activities are offered. Pet businesses, clubs and organisations are encouraged to attend to showcase their products and services.
The Pet Expo is held at Hadfield Park Wallan from 10am to 3pm.
Free entertainment is provided for Children including a petting zoo, jumping castle, face painter and balloon artist. Adults and children alike will enjoy displays of flyball and agility dogs. Try your dog out in the free lure course activity or participate in a puppy pre-school class. If you enter one of our competitions with your pet you could win a prize.
Discounted pet micro chipping will be available as well as reduced price Council Animal Registration.
If you are thinking of getting a pet in the future you will find information on a range of different pets and their welfare requirements.
To book a stall visit their website or for more information contact the Community Compliance Team on (03) 57346200.

item.title: Regenerate 2014 Festival
item.description:
Mitchell Shire Council invites residents to save the date and join the 'Regenerate 2014' community celebration in Hadfield Park in Wallan.
Fun on the days includes Emergency Services displays, live music, food and wine vendors, rides and activities.
Performers include: • Reece Mastin - winner of the X Factor 2011 and renowned for his #1 hit single "Good Night" • Tim Campbell - star of Home and Away and House Husbands will perform classic songs from his ARIA top 30 album "High School Disco". • Chocolate Starfish - One of Australia's favourite ARIA winning bands continues to rock the hits!
Time: 1pm-5pm - Free entry, all ages welcome!
For updates visit www.facebook.com/MitchellShire
Proudly supported by: • Regional Development Victoria • Bendigo Bank • Department of Human Services • Barry Plant • Kapish • Maddocks • Metropolitan Planning Authority • Metro Property Development • Preferred Training Networks • Roegen • sweett • Justitia • Hogens Hotel • Channel Nine
Acknowledging the strength of the community and our local emergency service providers.

item.title: Wedding Open Day - Peppers The Sands Resort Torquay
item.description:
Experience all things weddings at Peppers The Sands Torquay and meet with their Wedding Coordinator, suppliers and see all we have to offer!
Time: 11am to 3pm Price: Free
For more information on the Wedding Open Day an other events at Peppers The Sands Resort Torquay, please refer to their websit.e

item.title: Mitchell Shire Garage Sale Trail Day
item.description:
It's garage sales on the one big day right across Australia and the Mitchell Shire Council!
Garage Sale Trail is about re-using great stuff, reducing waste to landfill, meeting the neighbours, stimulating local economies, and providing an awesome platform for fundraising, all with the support of participating local councils.
See website for more information.

image.altText: Mitchell Shire Garage Sale Trail day
Mitchell Shire Garage Sale Trail day

item.title: Story Time on Saturdays
item.description:
Story time will be starting on Saturdays at the Wallan Library at 11am.
Introduce your child to the joys of rhymes, reading and the wonderful world of books with Mitchell Library Service’s free sessions.
